column10: Wowee.  What a good game.

As you can tell from the ~250 hours I've put into this game, I truly loved it.

However, the company and publishers who've made this game are a bunch of greedy cun7$ that deserve no money from me and won't be getting it ever again. This game was only special because of what it could have been,  and the love and dedication that people put into the mods for this game truly completed it, as when it was released (in a rush i'm sure for that stupid 11/11/11 date) the game was a complete buggy Bethesda mess. I only enjoyed my time in the game being able to mod it and try the things that other people were making out. Since this game's release Bethesda has continued their dramatic decline into money hungry sh!tshills. Everything they've made it seems like post the release of this masterpiece seems to have had $$$$ as it's sole focus. 

Screw the game, screw the story, screw the engine it's fine it works. These people disgust me and you should support them. smaller and smaller studios have been making better and better games, no need to waste time on over marketed, soul-less, money grubbing, bullsh!t like this. I mean truly, the last good games Bethesda made were PERHAPS fallout 4, and for sure fallout new vegas and 3.

Anything newer has been obviously reaching for your wallet and somehow worse and worse in performance each release. The games aren't fun, their engine sucks. You want to experience these stories? watch youtube videos, they respect your time and wallet more than these b@stards.

Curious if the old workshop files are still live with those l@zyCun t$ trying to charge for other people's passionate mod work. 

It's infuriating. Todd Howard is a POS.  I'd have recommended this but nobody will see this review, cause Bethesda missing half it's chromosomes and can't come up with a new idea to save its' life.

This comment is specifically written on the off-chance that some Bethesda executive or employee might read it some day. You suck, and you destroyed the love I had for your games. I  will NEVER pay you money for a damn thing again. My attitude has only been vindicated by seeing how awful Starfield is. Not worth a cent.

Hope y'all get your Sh!t together.

"At the request of the publisher, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is unlisted on the Steam store and will not appear in search."

This game is abandonware. You can no longer legally purchase the DLC for this software.
If you were to purchase the DLC, Steam would have added files to your Data directory which can be enabled or disabled like mods. Back in the day, we called these, "plugins", because they plug into your game.

Many mods will only work if you have Dawnguard.esm, Dragonborn.esm and sometimes Hearthfire.esm.
I'm writing this in 2024, at the time you can no longer buy this version or it's DLC's. So I'm technically better than you. 100/10

Skyrim need no introduction, so I'll just say this.
The game has kept me entertained for half of my life now, whether it was my first run on PS3, or now, modded to Oblivion and back. The game isn't perfect, it's bugged, unstable, kind of stiff when you think about it, but it's people's comfort place for a good reason. Even these many years later, when i can speedrun some of my favorite locations with my eyes closed, the game is still fun to revisit and try again.
Be a vampire, or a vampire slayer! Wecome a werewolf! A mage! A master assassin or a member of the thieves guild! Build your own home with friendly necromancer neighbours, marry your favorite follower, or get a mod and take the Moonpath to Elsweyr! Pretty much anything is possible if you want it to be.
if somehow you've never played it, i would 100% recommend it.

This happens to be my version of choice simply because the workshop has the mods I like and need for this one. I feel that's exactly what runs this game the most these days - mod support and vast range of choice among them. Quests, items, places, companions...you name it. Friendly dragons? Sure, why not.

Who doesn't know Skyrim given it re-released so many times it probably has fridge version somewhere too. Unsurprising though, I think it still holds title of the best Bethesda title. If I ever need a 'bethesda game' this is typically the best choice. By saying that it's one of those games where you keep redoing the same thing like yet another tomb and still find some addictive joy of exploration in it. All TES games have that, so do Fallouts...apparently not Starfield ;p
It's probably not the best TES entry but it's best balanced in terms of looking good, alright systems and passable writing. Certainly most accessible entry as well and, again, 2nd 3rd and 5th life breathed into it through mods.
Just for appropriateness sake to the newcomers I should generally say it's a high fantasy rpg where its most defining features are huge map with plenty of places of interest to explore, not too much intrusive plot to stand in a way of said exploration and skill system working around getting better in something as you simply do it. In addition this one in particular features and revolves around dragons but is of the slaying type, not petting ^.=.^""

When you sink over 600 hours into a single player game, you realise you can't criticise its faults as easily anymore. I could mention that Bethesda are awful at writing stories, and that all the NPC's have a personality of video game executives presenting at E3. I could mention that a lot of the magic disappears after your first playthrough, or that you need mods to add replay value, or that bug testing is a joke at Bethesda.

But I still played over 600 hours and bought all the expansion content, so I must like something in Skyrim, like the world design, and the vistas after jumping up the side of a mountain, or installing a 200+ mod list and having it work, or that first experience that every modern Bethesda game does when you first step out of the introduction cave into a massive open valley, and seeing a large town in the distance and deciding to ignore the main quest and run off in the opposite direction to see where you end up... or accidently killing the chicken in Riverwood and having to massacre the entire town as they exact revenge on your evil chicken slaughtering ways.

THE BEST open world rpg to ever exist. Yes the modding community is amazing, but even just base game has so much to do and is incredibly fun and immersive. Melee combat has noticeably aged poorly. You will literally never run out of things to do in this game. Bethesda is known for many fumbles, but every single Elder Scrolls is a masterpiece during it's own time and dominates gaming culture.

Honestly, the vanilla Skyrim never really appealed to me, even on the day it released. I prefer when the Elder Scrolls had more RPG mechanics.

However, Skyrim is arguably the most moddable game in history. So every single thing I didn't like about the game, I changed. And for that, it is theoretically able to be anyone's perfect game. My install is perfect for me.

"The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim," developed by Bethesda Game Studios and released in 2011, is an open-world action RPG that has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. Set in the sprawling, snow-covered province of Skyrim, the game immerses players in the life of the Dragonborn, a prophesied hero born with the power of The Voice, on a quest to defeat Alduin, a dragon who is foretold to destroy the world. This review assesses "Skyrim" based on its gameplay mechanics, story and world-building, graphical and audio presentation, modding community impact, and overall entertainment value.

Gameplay Mechanics
Rating: 8/10 - Good
"Skyrim" offers an expansive open-world experience, allowing players to explore at their leisure, from towering mountains to deep dungeons. The game features a wide variety of skills, from combat and magic to crafting and stealth, enabling diverse character builds and playstyles. While the freedom to choose one's path is a hallmark of the experience, some players might find combat mechanics to be less refined compared to more recent titles, with occasional clunkiness in melee combat and AI behavior.

Story and World-Building
Rating: 9/10 - Excellent
Bethesda excels in creating a rich, immersive world teeming with lore, factions, and history. The main questline, involving the Dragonborn's battle against Alduin, is complemented by numerous side quests and stories that delve into Skyrim's culture, politics, and mythology. The depth of the world-building contributes significantly to the game's allure, encouraging exploration and interaction. However, some narrative elements can feel disjointed, and the impact of player choices on the game's world is sometimes limited.

Graphical and Audio Presentation
Rating: 7/10 - Good
Upon release, "Skyrim" was praised for its beautiful, dynamic environments and atmospheric sound design, including an iconic soundtrack by Jeremy Soule. Over time, the base game's graphics have aged, with textures, character models, and animations falling behind modern standards. Nevertheless, the game's visual and audio presentation still manages to capture the epic and mystical essence of Skyrim, aided significantly by the modding community's enhancements.

Modding Community Impact
Rating: 10/10 - Masterpiece
One of "Skyrim's" most enduring legacies is its vibrant modding community, which has continually expanded and revitalized the game with graphical overhauls, new quests, gameplay tweaks, and bug fixes. The ease of modding and the sheer volume of available mods have significantly extended the game's lifespan and appeal, offering tailored experiences that range from the serious to the absurd.

Overall Entertainment Value
"Skyrim" offers an unparalleled level of freedom and immersion, making it a landmark title in the RPG genre. The game's vast open world, rich lore, and the ability to shape one's adventure provide hundreds of hours of gameplay. Despite its technical and mechanical shortcomings, the overall entertainment value is heightened by the game's moddability, ensuring its place in the hearts of gamers for years to come.

Overall Summary:
"The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim" remains a monumental achievement in video game design, offering a deeply immersive and customizable experience. Its impact on the RPG genre and gaming culture is undeniable, offering a blend of exploration, storytelling, and player freedom that has set a benchmark for open-world games.

A must-buy all-time masterpiece for all RPG fans and those seeking an expansive, immersive gaming experience. "Skyrim" is a must-play title that offers endless adventures in a world that feels alive and ripe for exploration.

"Skyrim" has cemented its status as one of the most influential and beloved games of its generation. Its legacy is not just in the countless hours spent exploring its rich landscape but also in how it has inspired a community of players and modders to keep the world of Skyrim alive and evolving. Whether you're shouting dragons from the sky, delving into ancient ruins, or simply gazing at the northern lights from a mountaintop, "Skyrim" promises an adventure that is as boundless as your imagination.

Hey fellow gamers, gather 'round for a tale of epic proportions, the saga of Skyrim! Picture this: I embarked on a journey so immersive that I forgot to eat, sleep, or even blink for days on end. I've emerged from my gaming cocoon a changed person - more like a potato than a human, but hey, who's judging?

Let me set the stage for you. I boot up Skyrim, innocent and full of hope. Little did I know, I was about to be sucked into a black hole of dragons, shouting, and more cheese wheels than I ever thought possible. Within minutes, I was hooked like a fish on a line, except instead of water, it was a sea of mead and molten lava.

The first thing that struck me was the graphics. Oh boy, they were so breathtakingly mediocre that I wept tears of joy. Who needs next-gen when you've got textures that look like they were hand-painted by a blindfolded toddler? And don't even get me started on the character models - I've seen more realistic faces on a Picasso painting.

But let's talk about the NPCs. These guys are like broken records stuck on repeat. I swear, every villager in Skyrim has the memory of a goldfish and the conversational skills of a particularly dim rock. "I used to be an adventurer like you, then I took an arrow to the knee." Yeah, yeah, we've all heard it a million times, mate. Get a new hobby!

And then there are the dragons. Oh, the majestic dragons! They soar through the sky with all the grace of a drunk pigeon, spewing fire and terrorizing the populace. But fear not, for I, the mighty Dragonborn, am here to save the day! Armed with a rusty sword and the power of shouting in Draconic, I valiantly charge into battle, tripping over my own

What is there left to be said about the elder scrolls V: Skyrim. Its been a beautiful journey with this game. On steam I only have 400 hours but had many more when I was introduced to this world on Xbox.

From the second your character wakes up you are pulled into this world that rivals the depth of tolkien himself. You are immediately given the problems of the world, that being dragons and war, in one of the most spectacular game opening I have experienced and we have only just begun. 

Once into the actual world you are greeted with a unique art style and with the help of Jeremy Soules soundtrack you are brought into the world of tamriel. The most mundane tasks like picking butterflies and thistles for alchemy turn into a sort of therapy. While the random encounters may be repetitive they have earned a special place in my heart. 

The quests, both main and side quests, just drive you further into the lived in world. From the thieves guild to the vampires each faction gives you a story and a call to action that truly makes you feel like more than the dragonborn. 

And lastly, where would skyrim be without the modders. The modding community has kept this game alive and thriving throughout the years. Taking the gift that were given and expanding on it like we have never seen. The cultural impact this game has had on not only myself but this generation of gamers has exceeded all expectation I had when I picked up my first copy on a fateful night at game stop. The only other game that I would compare this too is half life, both games have given people opportunities to expand themselves and test their personal limits when it comes to game development. There is no doubt in my mind that this game will continue to thrive and stand the test of time. Thank you Bethesda for this gift and thank you to the modders that keep this game going today.

Skyrim is a game with endless possibilities. You can create your own character, choose your playstyle, and explore a vast and beautiful world. Whether you want to save the world from dragons, join a faction, or just wander around, Skyrim lets you do it.

The game has a fantastic engine that allows you to mod it to your liking. There are thousands of mods available that add new content, features, graphics, and more. Some of the mods that I recommend are [SkyUI], which improves the user interface, [Ordinator], which overhauls the perk system, and [Immersive Weapons], which adds hundreds of new weapons to the game.

The gameplay is fun and engaging, with a variety of quests, locations, and characters to discover. You can fight with swords, bows, magic, or stealth, and customize your skills and equipment. Some of the most memorable quests for me were The Dark Brotherhood, which involves assassinating targets, The Thieves Guild, which involves stealing and sneaking, and The College of Winterhold, which involves learning and using magic.

The game also has amazing graphics, music, and voice acting. The landscapes are stunning, the soundtrack is epic, and the voice actors are talented. The game creates a rich and immersive atmosphere that makes you feel like you are part of the world.

The only thing that I think is missing from the game is a multiplayer option. Playing alone can be boring at times, and I would love to share my adventures with my friends. Luckily, there is a mod called Skyrim Together Reborn that allows you to play Skyrim in co-op with your friends or strangers. This mod is an overhaul for the game that adds new features, lore-friendly replacers, and translations for various languages. However, you should also be aware that this mod is still in development and may have some bugs or compatibility issues. You should also read the mod’s requirements and installation instructions carefully before trying it out.

Skyrim is the best RPG game out there for me, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves fantasy, adventure, and freedom. It is a game that you can play for hundreds of hours and never get bored. It is a game that you can make your own. It is a game that you can enjoy with your friends. Buy it!

My review used to say that Special Edition is objectively better for modding over 10 years after the original release. That is still mostly the case due to most Oldrim mods having been ported to SE, some vanilla quality of life improvements in SE, and many mods built for SE that either don’t have official Oldrim versions or simply cannot be ported to Oldrim. 
That being said, Oldrim still works for many. If you are content with not having features of Special/Anniversary edition or don’t want to deal with Bethesda updating the game in a way that may break several mods, go for it. I wouldn’t bet on Bethesda never updating Oldrim again, so it would help to prepare backups or workarounds for forced updates.

Skyrim is an timeless, epic game with a massive world, endless possibilities and a very strong replay value.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim has a relatively simple, but powerful story. Because this game is mainly focused on this story, I will spoil nothing. If you never played the game, this is something that you need to experience for yourself.

You start an empty character from various races, can customize almost every inch of their bodies and then start your adventure in the world of Skyrim. You are free to roam wherever you want, when you want, how you want, all at the very start of the game, after the tutorial. This game is the definition of “nonlinear” and freedom.

Right from the start, you get sucked into its beautiful open world, and can start leveling up your skills, picking some flowers, mine some ore, collect garbage to sell at vendors and finally murdering that bunny that you chased all the way to Riften.  

Even today, I still think Skyrim looks glorious. Sure, the textures can be a little rough here and there, animations are not as “flawless” as today’s games and flowers can look like cardboard cutouts, but for its time, this was revolutionary. There is just so much detail in everything. Wildlife, flowers, sunlight, moonlight, grass, mountains, it is all just great. Every cabin, every cave and every ruin is filled with countless items, details and decorations, and you can interact with almost all of it. Sure, this is a Bethesda game, so glitching and clipping is a thing, but that is the whole charm of this game. Seeing a bucket being launched at 320 km/h because it was too close to a table is just hilarious. 

Enemies are greatly designed and form a well balanced mix of beasts, monsters, bandits and supernatural beings.

Sound wise, Skyrim is a work of art. The sound effects, voice acting, and (ambient) music is just perfect. When walk around town, just wanting to buy some supplies, a calm and peaceful track plays in the background. When you get ambushed by a hungry dragon and the male orchestra voices play, you now that sh!t just got serious. 

The menu’s, controls and interfaces work great and the overall mechanics of the game are pretty realistic. You can become overburdened with all the crap you carry with you, you can attract vile diseases from certain enemies like the Skeevers (giant rats), you can experience serious problems or debuffs when not sleeping enough, it just adds more fun and challenge to the game. 

Combat works flawlessly and, with the right fighting style, can be intense and brutal. The beauty of the combat and learning curve, it is that you get nuked in the beginning by a Giant for example, level up your Heavy Armor skill, health and One Handed, come back to him, and shove that club of his so hard into his brown star until he finally gets the message that you are done with his sh!t.

The leveling system is also pretty unique, same as Fallout 3 for example. Instead of killing stuff and earn XP, you level all different skills by performing attacks or action in that category. Crouching past enemies undetected increases your Sneak, forging a million iron daggers improves your smithing, letting yourself get bludgeoned like a baby seal while wearing light armor increases your “Light Armor” skill etc. By leveling up your different skills, you earn general XP for your character level. With each new level, you can increase health, stamina, magika (mana) and choose a unique ability in the skill tree of one of your skills.

I especially love figuring out all the exploits the game has to level up your skills faster, try to move your horse over a 90 degrees slope, trying to get to space with the help of a giant and overall, fully explore (and exploit) everything this great game has to offer.

The best part of The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is simply that there is just soooooo much to do. You got a gigantic world map with hundreds of caves, crypts, enclaves, towns, cities, outposts, ruins, tombs and bandit camps, all waiting for you to explore, conquer and plunder. There are (in my opinion) a million quests to undertake and, like many, I got so caught up in the side quests, that I actually reached level 50 and still needed to visit the Greybeards, who almost died of old age when I finally got there. You can experiment with your skills, different weapons, different play styles and overall, this game can hook you up for literal days in terms of playtime.

This is one of those games in which you actually feel really powerful when leveling up enough, and all your hard work is actually reflected through your damage output, constitution and overall feel. This sounds pretty basic, but a lot of games do not actually reward you with power or feeling of might and pride when you reach level 80 for example.

Enemies level along with you, keeping the game and experience gain for your skill balanced, but there simply comes a point that they stand no chance anymore and if you are willing to spend two hundred hours of play in a character, this time is rewarded. With Sneak and Archery leveled to 100, every arrow is a insta kill and five enemies can be killed in five seconds while you are hidden. 

This is also the only small problem with Skyrim. At one point, you are so stupidly powerful (all skills maxed) that there is just no challenge and point anymore. It will takes thousands of hours for this point to be reached, but eventually, you are just too strong. 

In the end, I think The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is one of the best games ever made, and although it is considered a relic in present days, it’s legacy lives on forever in forms of memes, jokes, punch lines and references. It gives you worth for your money and in my opinion, every gamer is obligated to have this piece of art in their library.

Definitely recommend this timeless classic.

Absolutely wonderful game, I've had tons of fun playing it on both PC and 360, though if you haven't played it yet and are still considering purchasing it, absolutely get the PC version. 

While the developers pushed out a few patches, the game is still fraught with bugs, and numerous times I would encounter one of these issues on console and be unable to do anything about it except reloading my save and praying that fixed it. (90% of the time, reloading didn't fix it). I'm talking game-breaking bugs, too. Thankfully, dedicated players created the Unofficial Skyrim Patch, which you can easily install on PC versions and is a real lifesaver.

All in all, if you enjoy 'western' RPGs where you can build your character however you want, and you enjoy large environments to explore, letting you choose the order you complete objectives, this is for you. For those looking for a more linear experience, it might be a little overwhelming when you first walk out of the tutorial area and the whole country literally opens up to you. 

Combat moves in real time; there is no turn-based strategy here. It follows the same style as previous Elder Scrolls titles. With that in mind, now in 2017 it might feel a little janky, but it still holds up and is pretty easy to learn. Your character's skills (both combat and non-combat) increase the more you actually use them, which I personally really love. While different races at the start have a few points in specific areas, you can really build them however you want. Want an orc that's a real smooth-talker and favors archery? You can do that.

Considering this is the 5th entry in the Elder Scrolls series, there is background lore, and it will dump a bunch of terms unfamiliar to players at the start if they haven't played previous entries. (I was one of those people). Thankfully the game offers plenty of ways through dialogue, books, and quests to learn the story, and (the fun part) to build your own around it. For those uninterested in story, you don't really need to know or pay attention to any of it to progress through the game.

The major boon to playing on PC: MODS. The modding community for The Elder Scrolls has always been strong, and it's no exception for Skyrim. For those who enjoy a purely vanilla experience, you can do that, sure. But there are hundreds, if not thousands of talented and creative people who have essentially given access to free DLC, and you can make your own with the Creation Kit Bethesda released right here on Steam.

Speaking of DLC, both story DLC, Dawnguard and Dragonborn, are absolutely worth it. The 3rd DLC, Hearthfire, is really for those looking to add some new 'home-making' functionality to the game. With Hearthfire, your Orc archer from before can also own his own farm, raise a pair of orphans he found, and bake delicious pastries. I'm not joking. Personally, that's right up my alley, but for some it's not their cup of tea, so they won't be buying it. That being said, keep in mind the Legendary edition of the game comes bundled with all 3 DLC.

Let's start with what's actually good here:
-OST
-Atmosphere! Arguably the strongest point of the game, especially combined with the music. It can be nice to just walk around and look at a setting that has held up shockingly well for its age.
-more mods than I know what to do with (I guess they're paid now? fuck that)

Now for the bad*:
-combat feels stiff and unsatisfying, even the unique death animations wear out their welcome pretty quick
-despite being the flagship feature, dragons are pretty poorly implemented and aren't all that exciting to fight IMO
-frequently rewards the player for breaking immersion (be real, you didn't naturally progress your blacksmithing skill, you made 500 iron daggers in a row and were suddenly a master)
-RPG elements have regressed from Oblivion, which was itself a regression from Morrowind in this regard
-allowing the player to become faction leader of all factions (with the exception of whichever civil war side you don't choose) in a few in-game days cheapens all of them (the mage's guild in particular stands out here, you can put the bare minimum into spellcasting and get to be archmage in an in-game week)
-main quest is forgettable nonsense


*most of these can be addressed with mods. The above criticism is directed strictly at the base game.

If you like RPGs and dark fantasy, this is the game for you. After finishing the main storyline, I found myself going back more than once to play it again (even though it's not the best, or even good). The game has plenty of side missions that are quite fun to do. The ability to create characters freely, from appearance to armor, and combine different classes is very cool so that the game doesn't get boring quickly (one day you can run around as a typical archer in light armor and the next day as a mage in heavy armor). When I got bored with the main storyline and side missions, I started modding this game, and you can make a completely different game out of it. The resource of mods is so huge that you can change whatever you like. For me, this game is already partly a classic, to which I will certainly return.

아름다운 오픈월드 RPG.

오랜 시간 나는 태양이 내리쬐는 드넓은 대초원과 얼어붙은 설원의 꼭대기와 어둡고 거대하며 끝없는 동굴과 낡고 오래된 고대의 유적과 수많(지는 않)은 도시를 다녔다. 나는 한때 마법사였고 전사였으며 도적이었고 사냥꾼이었으며 언젠가는 용을 부리는 구세의 기사였다가 9개 주에서 현상금이 걸린 스카이림의 공적이 된 적도 있었다. 나는 때론 종족을 불문한 청년의 모습이었고 때론 노인의 모습이었으나 대부분의 시간은 아름다운 인간의 모습으로 존재했다. 

내게 주어진 세계는 매번 새로웠고 도시 안팎의 사람들과 생물체들 역시 내게 자주 다른 모습을 보여주었다. 그런 즐거움에 빠져 세계를 도는 횟수가 많아질수록 세계가 열리는데 걸리는 시간은 늘어났으나 다행스럽게도 그 시간은 충분히 보상받곤 했다. 나는 기뻤다.


긴 시간이 지나고, 나는 이제 스카이림의 세계가 아닌 다른 세계들을 여행한다. 핵전쟁으로 황폐해진 폐허를 벗과 오랜 기간 거닐기도 하였고 갖가지 환경에서 스카이림의 괴수보다 더욱 커다랗고 다양한 괴물들을 사냥하는 것을 업으로 삼고 지내기도 하였다. 뙤약볕 아래 공룡들을 길들이며 섬에서 탈출하려고 애써보기도 하고, 아름다운 소녀들과 해변에서 비치발리볼을 즐기기도 하였으며, 지구의 곳곳에서 일어나는 응급상황을 전화받고 처리하다가, 또 여전사가 되어 활과 총을 능숙하게 다루며 초현실적인 세계의 비밀을 캐내기도 했다.

모든 세계가 항상 즐겁지는 않았지만, 대부분의 시간은 즐거웠다. 그러나 기쁜 곳은 매우 드물었으며, 스카이림만큼 기뻤던 곳은 없었다.


검은 화면이 전환되며 세계가 새로이 열리던 시간. 그리고 내가 온전히 누릴 수 있는 자유를 떠올릴 때마다, 나는 내가 게이머로서 참으로 기뻤던 시간을 기억한다.

아직도 선명하게 떠오르는 스카이림의 시작을 추억하며.

"The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim" is a masterpiece in open-world RPG gaming, offering a vast, beautifully detailed world brimming with adventure and lore. This was my first Bethesda title and may I say it still holds its #1 spot on my list. Even through time Skrim sill holds its place up against RPG's of today. The main quest, centered around the Dragonborn's battle against Alduin, is compelling, but the true magic lies in the side quests and expansive exploration. Players can tailor their character's skills to their playstyle, engage in a deep crafting system, and enjoy an iconic soundtrack that enhances the epic atmosphere. Despite its age and occasional bugs, Skyrim's immersive world and active modding community keep it relevant and endlessly captivating for RPG enthusiasts.

[Skyrim opens with an Imperial wagon driving four prisoners down a snowy
 mountain pass. All are seated and bound; the one dressed in finery is gagged.]

Ralof: Hey, you. You're finally awake. You were trying to cross the border,
       right? Walked right into that Imperial ambush, same as us, and that
       thief over there.

Lokir: Damn you Stormcloaks. Skyrim was fine until you came along. Empire was
       nice and lazy. If they hadn't been looking for you, I could've stolen
       that horse and been half way to Hammerfell. You there. You and me -- we
       should be here. It's these Stormcloaks the Empire wants.

Ralof: We're all brothers and sisters in binds now, thief.

Imperial Soldier: Shut up back there!

[Lokir looks at the gagged man.]

Lokir: And what's wrong with him?

Ralof: Watch your tongue! You're speaking to Ulfric Stormcloak, the true High
       King.

Lokir: Ulfric? The Jarl of Windhelm? You're the leader of the rebellion. But if
       they captured you... Oh gods, where are they taking us?

Ralof: I don't know where we're going, but Sovngarde awaits.

Lokir: No, this can't be happening. This isn't happening.

Ralof: Hey, what village are you from, horse thief?

Lokir: Why do you care?

Ralof: A Nord's last thoughts should be of home.

Lokir: Rorikstead. I'm...I'm from Rorikstead.

[They approach the village of Helgen. A soldier calls out to the lead wagon.]

Imperial Soldier: General Tullius, sir! The headsman is waiting!

General Tullius: Good. Let's get this over with.

Lokir: Shor, Mara, Dibella, Kynareth, Akatosh. Divines, please help me.

Ralof: Look at him, General Tullius the Military Governor. And it looks like
       the Thalmor are with him. Damn elves. I bet they had something to do
       with this.

       This is Helgen. I used to be sweet on a girl from here. Wonder if Vilod
       is still making that mead with juniper berries mixed in. Funny...when I
       was a boy, Imperial walls and towers used to make me feel so safe.

[A man and son watch the prisoners pull into town.]

Haming: Who are they, daddy? Where are they going?

Torolf: You need to go inside, little cub.

Haming: Why? I want to watch the soldiers.

Torolf: Inside the house. Now.

[The wagon stops near the chopping block.]

Imperial Soldier: Whoa.

Lokir: Why are they stopping?

Ralof: Why do you think? End of the line. Let's go. Shouldn't keep the gods
       waiting for us.

Lokir: No! Wait! We're not rebels!

Ralof: Face your death with some courage, thief.

[Under the Imperials' watchful eye, the prisoners start jumping out.]

Lokir: You've got to tell them! We weren't with you! This is a mistake!

Imperial Captain: Step toward the block when we call your name. One at a time!

Ralof: Empire loves their damn lists.

Hadvar: Ulfric Stormcloak. Jarl of Windhelm.

Ralof: It has been an honor, Jarl Ulfric!

Hadvar: Ralof of Riverwood. Lokir of Rorikstead.

Lokir: No, I'm not a rebel! You can't do this!

[He makes a break for it.]

Imperial Captain: Halt!

Lokir: You're not going to kill me!

Imperial Captain: Archers!

[Lokir is downed with one bowshot.]

Imperial Captain: Anyone else feel like running?

Hadvar: Wait, you there. Step forward. Who are you?

The game is good. 7/10.

It does a lot of things very poorly (e.g. optimization, combat, magic, some skill trees), some other things are just mediocre (e.g. dialogue options, writing/quest lines, some other skill trees) and a handful of things are done very well (e.g. music, visual world design, scale, general vibes/atmosphere). You'd think that would make the game around a 4/10 overall, but those few good things do some serious heavy lifting.

It's quite easy to fall in love with this game at first sight, probably thanks in large part to it's aforementioned biggest strengths being things that heavily affect surface-level appeal and initial impressions. I for one am guilty of becoming a white knight for Bethesda and refusing to acknowledge the game being any less than perfect. See below my first review of Skyrim.

"This game has to be my all time favourite. Although many people who were introduced to The Elder Scrolls series earlier than myself would argue that Skyrim is dumbed down and falls short of the greatness of earlier titles such as Morrowind or Oblivion, I absolutely love it. The game has great aesthetics, a huge amount of lore and best of all, an amazing modding community. Although i personally love the character customisation, questlines, skill trees, DLC, craftable weaposn and armor, combat style and quite frankly, every aspect of this game, i understand most of these arent everyones cup of tea. Regardless though, i would highly recommend this game despite it being released almost four years prior to this review. Also, can't wait for The Elder Scrolls VI! That is, whenever Bethesda decides to make it (The next Fallout installment is probably coming first though :/ )"

It is also quite easy to grow to hate this game. As they say, love and hate are two sides of the same coin, and a common example of this is when something you thought you loved betrays your expectations. As I said before, Skyrim is very good at creating a positive initial impression, but it also has a lot of issues. These may be easy to overlook at first, but are likely to become more tedious and obvious the longer you play. Add in a splash of overzealous fandom and it's not hard to see how someone might not realize how far short the game falls of their expectations until after they've already invested a lot of time and energy. Even if they don't go as far as seeking revenge due to a sense of betrayal, someone in this position may simply become extra harsh on the game out of a desire to push developers toward creating games that do actually live up to the idea they fell in love with. Once again, I myself am guilty of turning from fanboy to hater overnight for similar reasons. See below the edit I made to my initial review around this time.

"Addendum, I wrote this when I was 15 and had never played an RPG before in my life. Skyrim is hot garbage, Bethesda is particularly hot garbage. Power to you if you can enjoy the game, but from a critical standpoint it's absolute trash. Even for it's time, the only thing it impressed in was graphics, and even that field was kinda meh compared to a lot of less hyped titles coming out at the time. If you've never played an RPG before, then by all means, but if you're coming from something like The Witcher or a popular indie title, you're gonna find a clunky, extremely poorly aged mess full of glitches and poor writing. Talk about a 180 in opinon, huh? Guess that's what happens when you appeal to an audience of people who don't know any better, then those people grow up."

The idea of a game like Skyrim - a high-budget first-person action RPG adventure with a huge detailed world, deep lore, tons of player freedom and so on -  done well is still very exciting to me, and seemingly to a lot of other people (see Cyberpunk 2077 initial marketing and hype). Skyrim isn't that, but it is one of only a handful of games to attempt that, and while it does fall short it's still pretty fun. I recommend you play it if you haven't already.

With all that being said, if I could choose whether or not to buy Skyrim for the first time today, I would not. The game is fine, but personally I would rather not support a company like Bethesda.

Elder Scrolls Skyrim is one of the first PC games I played when I switched from console gaming. I was amazed by the stunning graphics and the immersive feel of the game, which made me feel like I was really in a fantasy world. The game was released in 2011, but it still looks great today, especially with the help of mods that enhance the visuals and add new features.

The game gives you a lot of freedom and choice in how you play. You can follow the main story or you can ignore the main story and explore the vast map, which is filled with hundreds of locations, quests, and secrets. You can join different factions, such as the Thieves Guild, the Dark Brotherhood, or the College of Winterhold, and complete their missions.

It is not a perfect game, though. It has its share of bugs and glitches, which can sometimes ruin the immersion or cause frustration. Some of the quests and characters can also be repetitive and bland, and the dialogue can be awkward and cheesy. The combat system can also be clunky and unbalanced, depending on your playstyle and the difficulty level. The game's user interface and inventory system can also be cumbersome and frustrating to use, especially on PC.

Despite its flaws, Elder Scrolls Skyrim is one of the best RPGs ever made and a must-play for anyone who loves fantasy and adventure. It offers a huge amount of content and fun for a reasonable price. It is a game that you can easily spend hundreds of hours playing and still find new things to do and see. It is a game that will make you feel like you are part of a living, breathing world that you can shape and influence with your actions. It is a game that you should not miss.

Such a glorious game! I was first introduced to this game back in 2013 when I was 9 through the VenturianTale YouTube series. I watched every episode of that series until it ended in 2014, and my desire for the game and love for it's plot and aesthetic sorta died down. In 2018, I purchased a copy of the Skyrim texture pack for Minecraft XBOX One, and that caused my love for the idea of Skyrim to be reinvigorated, but not for all too long. This past year, I got a 10-year-old Windows 10 Desktop computer for free and chose to purchase this game and accompanying DLC. After playing the game, I came to the wonderful realization that Skyrim was exactly how I envisioned it to be all those years ago back in 2013---including the bugs! I can't describe why or how I love this game, but I can safely say this game is one of, if not objectively, my favorite game.

Anyways, good game! Quite a few too many bugs, though. The Bloodborn DLC could have definitely used more time and effort before release too. The Dragonborn DLC is nearly better than the main game, though!

Been sucked into the world of Skyrim recently. I think when I last played a elder scrolls game (marrow wind) I was more interested in other games and the story didn't have me too involved since it was such a open world, however this is quite different and they've clearly improved in many places, especially one problem I found was the old journal system, this is FAR better and steam workshop to upload mods just makes it so much better to do simple things like fix errors, better UI, optional beginnings and so on. I haven't touched many of the cosmetic mods, but this game is definitely worth the price. However I recommend getting it only if you have the free time. It's a HUGE world and there are a lot of things to do in it no matter if you choose to be a somewhat nice guy or a evil bastard.

Edit: With time, this game has aged like milk from how the company keeps reposting the same damn game over and over again that has huge worlds, but next-to-no content in this world that they boast about whilst also being filled with bugs that the far better and more competent modding community have fixed decades ago, at this point!

It seems Bethesda are great at making these empty shell of a game, but, refuse to actually put anything into this shell and get angry when others out there fill it up with their own things. To the point that they are once again attempting to do the whole "paid mods" thing that they tried to get away with last time with Fallout 4 and the creation club, however, they didn't learn their lesson from last time. Especially, as pointed out, the mods on the creation club are nowhere near as good as those for free and they were FAR too restrictive in regards to what mods added, including going on about lore and such when they violate that far too much themselves!

I've given up giving Bethesda any money or benefit of the doubt because they've shown themselves that they don't care about the games themselves, but how much they can squeeze out of you. It's especially apparent in the DLC  they release often being the equivalent to mods you get for free, with some excuses.

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

Deadeye (Ultimate): McCree's Ultimate ability. When activated, McCree enters a special targeting mode for a short duration, during which time he is dramatically slowed and cannot use his other abilities. Enemies are gradually highlighted with a red bullseye as long as they are within McCree's vision. McCree can press the primary fire button at any point during this time to shoot a bullet at all highlighted targets, with the damage increasing the longer they were within McCree's vision. This is a channeled ability, and will immediately end if McCree is hit by a stun
Skyrim is popular for a reason, although you may want to consider the Special Edition or Anniversary Edition at this point.

Skyrim's Creation Club Disaster: A Decade of Greed

Rating: ★☆☆☆☆ (1/5)

It's hard to believe that after 12 years, Bethesda has managed to tarnish the legacy of Skyrim even further with its latest debacle, the Creation Club and the ill-fated attempt at reintroducing paid mods. What was once a groundbreaking open-world RPG has now become a sad testament to corporate greed and a blatant disregard for the gaming community.

Firstly, let's talk about the Creation Club. Bethesda had the audacity to repackage and re-release the same old content, slapping a hefty price tag on it as if it were something revolutionary. The so-called "new" creations are nothing more than recycled assets and uninspired ideas. It's clear that the focus here is on making a quick buck rather than delivering meaningful and innovative content to the players who have supported the game for over a decade.

The real kicker, however, is the reintroduction of paid mods. After the disastrous attempt nine years ago, one would have thought Bethesda had learned its lesson. Unfortunately, they seem to be deaf to the cries of the gaming community. The modding scene has always thrived on creativity, passion, and a sense of community. However, with paid mods, Bethesda is trying to turn this vibrant ecosystem into a profit-driven marketplace.

Not only are the prices exorbitant, but the quality of some of these paid mods is questionable at best. It's disheartening to see modders who were once driven by their love for the game now motivated solely by the pursuit of financial gain. This shift in focus has led to a decline in the overall quality and authenticity of the mods available.

The worst part is that Bethesda seems oblivious to the negative feedback pouring in from the once-loyal fanbase. The forums are filled with disgruntled players who feel betrayed by a company that was once known for its dedication to its community. It's as if Bethesda has lost touch with what made Skyrim special in the first place – the passion and creativity of its player base.

In conclusion, Skyrim's 12th-anniversary update, featuring the Creation Club and the misguided attempt at reintroducing paid mods, is a stain on the game's legacy. Instead of celebrating a beloved classic, players are left with a bitter taste of corporate greed and a sense of betrayal. It's a sad day for the gaming community when a once-revered title succumbs to the pitfalls of profit-driven decision-making.

Hey, you. You're finally awake.


10/10

The most amputated piece of software I have ever had the joy of being exposed to which also happens to be commercially available (as of writing this). That being said, the base story holds up pretty well for a blind run, but afterwards it is done for.

The DLCs are mid-tier, with the story-driven ones giving you only an ounce of content, whilst leaving you thristy for a complete package, a.k.a unfinished products. Considering the base game used to cost 14,99 euros and Dawnguard and Dragonborn used to both be 19,99 [b]RESPECTIVELY[/b], uhh yeah, hell no.

Special Edition licenses were given for free to Legendary Edition license holders (Base + the three paid DLCs [not the HD Texture patch]) and while this is [i]nice[/i], the trade-off of having an in-game shop for [b]PAID RESKINS[/b] in your edition of the game (consuming resources) for a 64-bit translation is a bit on the scales.

The original 32-bit version could be modded spectacularly (my hours are living proof of this) as long as you keep a common sense and don't go overboard with certain nuances of modding. A third party modification known as ENB Series (made by a single dude) allowed to bypass the built-in memory limitation of the 32-bit architecture, by creating additional instances (observable in your task manager) of itself and hooking it with Skyrim, effectively [b]ELIMINATING[/b] the architectural downside of Oldrim and rendering Special Edition obsolete in this regard.

But of course, the original had to be [strike]taken down[/strike] hidden when the "new" version appeared, in order to segregate the players and, furthermore, the modding scene.

The ones who mod the hell out of their games will not be saved by the 64-bit architecture, in fact, they will suffer more from it. The congested littery mindset injected into Special Edition is palpable at best.

One thing which old Skyrim used to have lacking however, is the fact it was only available on Steam. Some mods deliberately do not work with cracked Oldrims (because some people are sad and bankrupt on the inside), like Fore's New Idles. Special Edition [b][u]CAN[/u][/b] be obtained on GOG, which kind of boosts its standing a little bit I must admit.

Nevertheless, the original remains superior. Copy-pastes with a few minor tweaks will never justify a full price. Having no conceptual ideas or skills whatsoever.

The soundtrack is pretty good and deserves a bit of praise.

Other than that, it is a thumbs up. Suprisingly this game has earned it. Money well spent.

My wife has most of the hours on this account, as well as a couple hundred on a 360 and an xbone. She started to play it when we were dating and first moved in together 

For her, she hardly played most video games, but wanted to give it a try after I started a pllaythrough. She had the hardest time figuring out FPS movement on either a controller or K+M, but kept giving it a try. She kept going and with a little practice was finally able to play. 

I saw her light up when she played. It was beautiful watching her playfulness come out when she got shot with arrows and ducked her head. She hyped herself up while charging double flame spells. Hyperventilate breaths when she got caught sneaking. Excited she completed a story quest that tied into something else about Skyrim she didn’t understand yet. 

After she completed her own play through on the 360, we built a computer together and she discovered the joy of mods. Adding custom quests, replaying encounters with new gameplay elements, decorating her fancy house it was all joyous to her. I remember days she couldn’t wait to tell me about the new mod she added and how it changed the game and how excited she was to play it more. 

I liked Skyrim a bit, I like Morrowind better. But I will always love Skyrim and consider it the best Bethesda’s done not for the game, but for the way it made my then girlfriend, now wife so happy. It gave us an early way to communicate and to bond over playful things. It made me feel the same happy, excited kid to talk with her about video games like I hadn’t in a decades time. 

So I will always love Skyrim because I will always love her.

ETA 11/2023: I started a new save on my Playstation 5 and it really renewed the love and respect I have for this game. I know it's confusing that I chose not to just do a new one on PC, but there's a reason: on PC I found myself cheating via the console more than I would like. Unlocking doors when lockpicking got too annoying, instakilling dragons when I didn't feel like fighting them; and I wanted to play the game through genuinely at least once.

 I'm a little upset that Bethesda decided to move to SKSE and leave this one behind, because as far as I can tell you cannot move over your saves without a lot of trouble and compatibility issues (mods), and I started my PC save before SE was really a thing. I imagine once I finish my PS5 game I'll start a new one on SKSE eventually. I'll obviously review SKSE if I get it to work right with my save.


Original review:

I have played this game a lot (compared to other games). I've owned it for about two years? Not sure about the purchase date but I'm too lazy to check. This is going to be a quick little review of this game. 

Bethesda, you really did well here. There is so much to do and it's extremely immersive and fun. ESO (Elder Scrolls Online) seems like an interesting concept of making an online version but from what I can tell the single player Skyrim seems a lot better- but this isn't a review of ESO.

Perhaps one of the best parts of this game is the awesome modding potential- there is so much you can do and add to make your experience truly one of a kind, whether it be house expansions, a new GUI, or something as simple as a texture fix. The modding community is amazing, so don't think that if you finish it through once you're done- there's always more to do.

Some of the quests are a little boring, but they keep you around discovering new places which is fun. Perhaps the worst thing i've encountered so far is how long it takes to obtain gold for houses- it takes a bit. But that doesn't really change my opinion at all.  One minor annoyance is the fact that if you alt-tab into another application (for me, discord) it skrews with the game so you have to restart it so make it work properly (however, you are still able to save before starting, you have to WAIT)

Overall, if you're on the edge about getting it, DO IT. It is such a good game and It doesn't get enough credit. Bethesda really outdid themselves with this game. HOWEVER- The game goes on sale a lot, so if it isn't on sale now, just wait a little bit. (Add to your wishlist and they will email you when it is on sale). If I recall I got my copy for 15$.

Skyrim is simply one of the, if not the best fantasy RPG ever made. It boasts a massive world, total freedom within the story, and unlike starfield it is chock full of things to do, unique side quests, and quality DLC. Buy vanilla Skyrim. You WILL NOT REGRET IT.

The game itself, content wise, is amazing and it deserves it's massive acclaim.
That said, this game borders on unplayable, putting even Release Cyberpunk 2077 to shame.
For some reason Skyrim's bugs have gotten the "Funny haha bug" reputation, when in reality, it's marred with game-breaking or even game-ending bugs.
From broken npc behavior, broken quest scripting, crashes, freezes, black screens, random damage outputs, bad physics resulting in insta-deaths, scripts just not triggering and many more.
I have played almost 200 hours here on steam, almost 300 hours on ps3, and many more on "ill acquired" versions of the game.
As I have stated above, I have experienced Cyberpunk 2077 on release, and beat the game.
11 years later after it's release, Skyrim has barely seen any fixes, which becomes an even more evident issue when "Modern" PC components and Operating Systems start popping up.
This would be an understandable issue if the game had been abandoned by it's Developer/Publisher, but this is far from the case.
Bethesda hid the DLCs for this version from the steam store in an attempt to make people buy the Legendary Edition.
Just like Dark Souls Remastered, this is, for a lack of a better word, a scam.
Dark Souls released in a deplorable state for the PC, so instead of actually patching the game or giving the people who bought that mess a working game they charged 20€ ("""Discounted""") for what was basically a patch.
As it stands, the only way to actually play Skyrim nowadays is with one of the "Enhanced Editions", which I don't own, and most likely never will out of sheer spite.

TLDR: Unplayable in modern hardware (and even older hardware), either buy the "Enhanced Editions" or suffer through a frustrating bug filled slog...

While I would say I enjoy this game and it kills my free time, I have found it to be a bit of a let down. It was the first "real" game I played, and at the time when I had first played it I didn't have much to compare it to. I wanted to play it vanilla now that I've had a few years of experience other games.

I recently started playing it again - I do have an older version which I imagine contributes to my experience in terms of the bugginess of quests breaking etc, and I do try to take into consideration the fact that this game is a decade old. However, overall the game play is repetitive and at times the story and experience feel sloppy and uninteresting. It feels like the quests are the same thing over and over regardless of the guild, or if it's the main quest, or anything - and primarily this has to do with the dungeon design and combat. 

It's overall /fine/ but given how many people love this game, and the face they've been able to resell it like 7 times gave me expectation that the experience would be more than lackluster. I've also come to find frustration from other constantly saying "no, it's good! just download a bunch of mods!"

Should have written this years ago lolz, something about this game every-time you step come back, even years later there's some kind of feeling that draws you closer. The characters and stories are soo unique and deep you just want to know everyone's role in this large expansive world. Arriving into small towns like Riverwood you are greeted by a smile and wave, I suppose its the little things that add up to the whole bigger picture. The ability to choose who (You) wanted to become and contribute to the world is what I loved and what impact you would leave behind. As you traveled to many areas (provinces) the landscape changed constantly and you as the traveller got more and more lost in the whole world around you. I honestly felt so small in this world. Whether it was fighting for the Noble Stormclocks or staying Loyal to The Empire, or become a vampire an so much more, your fate was you to decide. The Heartfire DLC was amazing, and I bought a property as soon as I had the gold in my beloved town of Riverwood. Mods also breathed even more life into these games and adding much content it would be neverending to discuss. The Soundtrack made this game come alive even more I mean really good. It was a pleasure playing this game and I will remember the good times exploring this vast and forgotten land. This game will age very well

The 2011 fantasy role playing video game Skyrim developed by Bethesda is arguably the most influential modern game of all time. It set an entirely new standard of quality for triple A games to attempt to meet.

You are Dragonborn, meaning you are destined to save the world using your special powers. The world is in turmoil from war, but then things get worse when malignant dragons start to resurrect and attack the world. In Skyrim you will create your own character and forge your own journey forwards. There are many routes to take but at the end of it all you will hopefully bring peace to the world and end war and dragon-related conflict.

Skyrim is the definition of value. It's amount of content is staggeringly large to the point where you could genuinely question whether the game can actually be 100%ed or not. It's a beautiful game and every location you come across is unique and memorable. One of the craziest aspects of the game is that all of those cool snowy mountains you see in the "skybox," is actually not a sky box at all and is a genuine location you can go to yourself any time you wish.

The combat is super outdated in this game but it's functional and secondary to what the game is about. This is a massive scaled role playing adventure game focused on exploring and dialogue choices which is of course further improved by it's dedicated modding community. Looting and hoarding as much wealth and items as possible is also a very fun part of the game. There is so much to explore that you will never feel bored or like you have ran out of things to do at any stage of your playthroughs.

Skyrim is legendary so I have shown it some respect. Some of it's featured haven't aged super well but it's still very enjoyable and a must play to this day.

10/10.

Progression of a Skyrim player.

Part 1. 
New Elder scrolls you say, sure I'll snaffle the snack.

Part 2.
Well I guess another mouthful can't hurt.

Part 3.
Hundreds of hours in, and hundreds of snaffled mouthfuls of Bethesda's finest, you are now incapable of moving, your being is merged with your desk in an un-holy amalgamation of flesh, shoddily painted MDF, snack crumbs, and spittle. You turn in panic, realising the years that have passed, a cry escaping your lips, but your wife lies dead at your feet, eaten by the cat. Sugary tears, laced in MSG roll down your gargantuan frame with the dawn of your reality. Screaming you thrash. Screaming you flail. But your efforts are in vain. Todd Howard has you. Todd Howard will not let another flee. 

With a Herculean effort though you tear from your desk, crashing to the floor in a terrible fit. Paw over paw, your fat digits clamber, desperate for the door, desperate for salvation, desperate for a bath and low fat diet...seriously though, you smell like someone wiped week old bacon over a public restroom floor and used it for cologne. But within reach of the handle you hear his voice....it's Todd! You turn and he's there, shimmering like some Daedric trickster, There he cackles, his arms wide in mocking embrace. And where do you think you're going his eyes cry out....not from Todd. Never from Todd. You turn to lunge for salvation, but your hand is struck with DLC after DLC. But you are strong...aren't you. You mustn't look. Then a slap on your leg fells you and you roll to see the Special, ultra, legendary Edition, now with 3000 hours of extra content, and at no extra cost....new horse armour. OH GOD WHY WON'T YOU LET ME LIVE your mind howls, but it's too late. Your protestations ring hollow in your own fleeting consciousness as Skyrim claims you again. The warmth. The calming, familiar warmth. It is...happiness.

And you smile.

And you smile. 

And you smile. 

And you smile. 

And you smile.

And you smile.

This game can become your second life, only better! Quench your thirst for adventure or for picking random loot that you can put in your mouth... with consequences! Distracting side quests are aplenty. I don't play with mods (a heresy I hear) but the sheer nostalgia gets me through the bugs.
I have an addiction, it's been 12 years and can't stop playing, please help me!

Skyrim Has and always will be my most love game of all time. 100+ Hours In And I'm Still Hooked. It has something for everyone.

This game is engaging and fun, it leads you in the right direction but allows you to steer off the main plotline. I love this game, I played it years ago and I'm really glad to immerse myself back into it.
I really love this game, I've played since I was a kid and it's still good, it's one of the best games I've played, and I do not regret spending 1000 hours on it.

Skyrim is just.... really mid.

This was my first time playing a Bethesda game, and I fail to see why people like them. The plot is kinda aimless, the world is neat but oddly feels kind of dead, and there's [i]far[/i] too many bugs on top of a dogshit inventory UI that you're expected to use way too often.

The magic system is also as wide as an ocean, but as deep as a puddle. Every spell has 1 gimmick but doesn't interact with the world nearly as much as it should. It's like they went with the first draft of every idea they had.

It seems like Bethesda's RPGs are designed around the fact that you're gonna install a billion mods to make them even halfway functional - and that's not how game companies should design games.

Made me realize that I don't like RPGs though, so at least it's saved me some time.

Suggestions to Bethesda to improve the games functionality.

-Toggleable World Map. (filter to show only mines, only caves, property you own, etc).

-Higher Base Carry Weight. (if you can carry 100k pieces of gold + 1000's of arrows, then realistically, we can have at least 500 starting carry weight).

-Higher Base Vendor Gold
-More Inventory Categories (i.e. Ores, Ingots, Soul Gems, Jewellery, etc)
-Whistle Button For Horse

-More Than Two Adoptable Children. (if you can own up to 8 houses, you should be allowed to send any 2 orphans to be looked after by your housecarls (even if you are a mostly absent father/mother due to adventuring, it's much better that some of these orphans at least have a roof over their head and a warm place to sleep)).

Yes, I realise that most of these things can be installed, or fixed by just using a mod for this or that, but it's not about that.

It's about not having so many issues here and there with the base game that you end up resort to using mods because the base game lacks so many things.

[Edit]: Beast form won't cooldown. The No One Escapes Cidna Mine bugged my fast travel so I had backtrack a whole hour of gameplay.

Easily one of my favorite video games of all time and one of the best Elder Scrolls entries. Skyrim is one of the best games that I’ve had the honor to play. There’s a lot of reasons and I’ll list some of them. Firstly for a game of 2011 it has some great graphics and physics. The scenery is some of the best I’ve seen in a game. The best sceneries in a long time with the second being RDR2 and GTA V. I know there’s a lot of annoying memes and people hating for just playing the game but honestly I don’t really care. 

Skyrim does so many things right, the main quest line, characters, side quests, guilds, and a strong sense of freedom and the encouragement to explore more of the world. Without mods, I could easily devote hours into it. Whether it’s to level up, finding cool weapons, or anything else, it’s worth the time. The world building is fantastic, the sounds and ambience is awesome. The creatures and enemies are all unique and plenty of dungeons are unique and some are very large and diverse.

The main theme of Skyrim is one of my favorites in a video game. A weakened empire on its last legs with the threat of a greater foe who almost crushed them in a massive war, and dragons returning and you being the Dragonborn. A beautiful country tearing itself up for independence, and joining dark guilds and restore them to power. The soundtrack is some of the best. My favorites being “From Past to Present”, and “One they Fear”. 

The DLC is some of the best also. Dawngaurd has many strengths, being a vampire hunter among the Dawnguard with an interesting backstory, more weapons and side quests, the option to join a vampire clan and become the leader if you decide is the best. The main them of Vampires is highly awesome and worth the try. The quests in Dawnguard are some of the best. With my favorites being going to the Soul Carin and traveling through the Forgotten Vale. And the selling point is that you get one of the best and most interesting followers in the game.

And of course Heartfire is a awesome also. Relaxing from a day of adventure and treasure hunting and building a large home and starting a family is cool. You can also store some of your best loot and display them where you could feel proud of your achievements.

And of course Dragonborn. One of the best DLC’s in Skyrim. Going to Solstheim again and fighting the Last Dragonborn. Awesome locations and good storyline to get you engaged. Miraak has to be one of the most interesting and best villains in the Elder Scrolls. And of course you can’t forget good old Herma Mora.

Overall Skyrim is an amazing game and even though you’ve probably played it, come back to it a while later. And for a those who’ve haven’t played it, give it a shot. You won’t regret it.

One of the first games I've ever bought on steam and still one of my best investments. Sure, the game has major flaws. The combat system is mediocre at best, the main story is really not that interesting and some of the cities feel kinda pointless. Even so Skyrim offers dozens if not hundreds of hours of content and a truly unique and memorable journey. If you're into long fantasy RPGs, this is one you don't want to miss. The game is also home to one of the biggest modding communities. Mods really take this game to a whole nother level and potentially add many more hours of free content.

Happy 12 years, Skyrim!
Thank you for all the adventures!

A long time ago, Christmas of 2010 (I believe), my mum purchased Red Dead Redemption and a second-hand Xbox 360 for me at a car boot sale. This was an apparently shameful expense for her to justify spending, and so I was told to tell people (should they ask) that it cost her only £40.

What it actually cost, I’m not sure. 

By the next Christmas, the house had been repossessed, and we began the process of packing our lives into cardboard boxes whilst awaiting the purgatory of an emergency shelter. One of the last rooms packed was my mum’s, and, whilst doing so, she uncovered two gifts she had misplaced before Christmas; Halo: Reach, and The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim.

Though all three of these games were voraciously played to a point far beyond the natural lifespans of their available content (even without the internet to access Xbox Live, I still managed to grind my Spartan through the notorious Warrant Officer ranks and beyond), Skyrim was the one that seemed to totally captivate a desire within me to immerse myself in the world held within its little silver disk. I wanted to experience everything it had to offer.

In early 2013, we were moved from the shelter to a council house, where, for the first time, we got at-home internet access. This opened me up to a world of Skyrim YouTubers playing on PC, with mods, and (after all the hours I’d already spent playing Skyrim) I wanted to emulate what I was seeing. I did this by enforcing certain “immersive limitations” on my playthroughs by doing things like: regularly sleeping and eating, restricting the use of potions, forbidding the use of fast travel, and refraining from treating my hirelings like begrudged bipedal pack animals. 

I’m convinced I eventually spent somewhere north of a thousand hours wandering, and exploring, and experiencing everything from the deep autumnal birch forests of The Rift to the edges of Haafingar’s desolate tundratic coast. I was totally and utterly enthralled by the depth of it all.

During all of this, the things in our life that were bad only seemed to ceaslessly creep towards ‘worse’, yet Skyrim managed to occupy and distract my mind enough to help float me through a time so low in my life that I almost can’t recall it. I’m not saying Skyrim fixed a broken 14-year-old’s life; however, I reckon it did help him find a bit of solace at a time when his home life was really not so great.

For me, Skyrim was a dense, content-rich world with so much in it to discover. It’s one of a small number of truly unique games I wish I could forget all about, should it allow me to experience it, once again, for the very first time.

I hope that one day I’ll return.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim é um caso interessante, se comparado com outros nomes do gênero, e até mesmo da própria franquia Elder Scrolls, esse jogo pode sim ser considerado raso e abaixo da média, sua história, apesar de interessante, é bem básica, as quests em geral prendem o jogador mas tudo é muito mastigado, você consegue tranquilamente jogar esse jogo por inteiro sem prestar atenção em um único dialogo nem ler aqueles textos que aparecem na tela de seleção de quests, apenas lendo o pop-up que aparece na tela após o inicio da quest.
Sua gameplay é divertida e intuitiva, mas para aqueles que procuram um grande desafio esse não é o jogo, Skyrim é um jogo fácil, até mesmo nas dificuldades mais altas é possível jogar sem grandes dificuldades, talvez o maior desafio inicialmente sejam os dragões e os trolls, que causam um dano bem considerável. Os puzzles presentes nas dungeons também são bem básicos e não geram um grande desafio., e as dungeons em si também não são tão interessantes, e chegam até a serem repetitivas.
Skyrim possui um sistema bem intuitivo de crafting, é possível criar equipamentos, poções, encantar e aprimorar itens, mas nada disso é essencial para a sua progressão, a não ser que o seu objetivo seja conseguir os equipamentos Daedra, por exemplo, você consegue tranquilamente adquirir um bom equipamento apenas contando com o drop de itens em baús e em corpos inimigos.
O sistema de dialogo e negociação é péssimo e não exige nada do jogador, desde o nível 1 você consegue persuadir tranquilamente desde guardas a generais e Jarls, diferente da franquia Fallout, por exemplo, onde se você não tem o nível necessário para isso se torna impossível persuadir e negociar de forma bem sucedida. O sistema de lockpicking é interessante e bem intuitivo, é preciso upar bem para conseguir abrir as trancas que exigem um nível maior, ou criar um save antes e ficar tentando até conseguir.
O sistema de sneaking é bem trabalhado, mas como não segui essa linha de gameplay não posso opinar detalhadamente.
A árvore de skills é um ponto positivo, grande mas não de forma exagerada e a medida que você vai evoluindo é notável a diferença que cada habilidade adquirida traz para a sua gameplay.
Um dos pontos que mais gostei de Skyrim é o sistema de magias e "shouts", aqui você não vai desbloqueando essas habilidades a medida que ganha nível, mas sim a medida que você explora o mapa e as dungeons, achando livros de spells com novas magias e as "Word Walls" com novas "shouts"
O sistema de criação de personagem é interessante, cada raça possui suas vantagens e desvantagens, a personalização é bem abrangente e é interessante ver a forma como as pessoas tratam você dependendo da raça que você escolhe, mas também não é nada que mude a progressão da história, já que acabam sendo apenas frases soltas entre os diálogos.
O visual é bem datado, mas pode ser corrigido com mods, desde o mais leve que ajusta a saturação das cores até o mais pesado que transforma Skyrim em um jogo completamente novo. Os bugs são bem presentes, na maioria das vezes são coisas bobas como itens flutuando no cenário mas vz ou outra é possível se deparar com bugs que atrapalham a gameplay, como uma vez onde uma personagem de uma quest se tornou completamente estática e impossível de se interagir e foi preciso eu carregar um save para o início quest e refaze-la.
No geral, Skyrim é um bom passatempo (e digo isso com propriedade, tendo quase 300 horas de jogo), sua gameplay prende o jogador e suas quests sem muita profundidade tornam o jogo uma ótima porta de entrada para aqueles que querem entrar no mundo dos RPGs eletrônicos, porém, para aqueles que estão acostumados com jogos densos, com gameplay e sistemas mais complexos, Skyrim pode ser uma experiência bem broxante.

Ah, Skyrim... The game so legendary that even your grandma has probably Fus Ro Dah'd a dragon off a cliff. Do we even need reviews at this point? 

But hey, for the few of you who've been living under a rock, or perhaps just waiting for it to be released on smart fridges (let's be honest, it's only a matter of time), here's a glimpse into the magical world of Tamriel's frostiest province.

Imagine a world where you're less "Dragonborn, Savior of the Realm" and more "Local Delinquent with a Lockpick Fetish." You'll spend nights perfecting the fine arts of thievery: lockpicking, sneaking, and the delicate craft of pocket-filching. Just picture it: The sun sets, the moon rises, and there you are, creeping into someone's house, only to be caught because you forgot to place a pot over the homeowner's head. Classic rookie mistake!

And if you thought learning a second language was hard, try leveling up in Skyrim. This game has more skills than that "optional extra package" they always try to upsell you on when you're buying a new car. From baking bread to battling dragons, from negotiating with giants to...well, yodeling off mountaintops (or shouting, same difference), you've got options! And none of them come with a smarmy salesman and an overpriced extended warranty.

So, whether you're seeking glory in the ancient Nordic tombs or simply looking to adopt a couple of kids after accidentally "removing" their parents (don't ask), there's a place for you in this vast realm. But a word of caution: Watch out for those pesky arrows! For some inexplicable reason, knees in Skyrim are arrow magnets. I swear, they should start an insurance company just for that.

In summary: If you've ever wanted to be simultaneously adored, feared, and confused by an entire continent, then Skyrim is your jam. Dive in, Dovahkiin, and may your knee armor be ever sturdy!

Wow, this game really pulled me for hundreds of hours to the exclusion of all others for a while.  The world building is incredible, and you just want to keep exploring, finding countless things to distract you from the main quest.  This is actually a good thing, as some of the best experiences for me were during side quests.

I have to admit that my game time also includes many hours playing with my daughter, spawning in Whiterun, jumping on a horse, riding past the giant camp, past whatever wild animal was going to spawn on the way up the mountain to see the dragon.  We used to see how close we could get without waking it.  Once it woke up, we'd turn tail and canter away as fast as possible back down the mountain to the lake, where we'd watch the angry dragon attack the giants, or whoever else was around.  Happy days!

I've come back to this game quite a few times over the past 9ish years, and I love it every time. There are so many places to explore, so many different types of characters you can play, and multiple paths you can take through the quests, so it always feels like a new adventure, even if you're playing the game for the 10th time.

Are there better more polished and more complex games that can compete? Sure. Were they released just at the right time to build foundational memories and be forever ingrained in me mind as "the good old times" kind of game? 100% no. This is the one and only.

In Skyrim's world, a tale of disdain,
Launched with novelties, yet bugs left a stain.
Mods came to rescue, a community's feat,
But Bethesda's approach, bitter and sweet.

A realm of dragons, shouts, and lore,
Yet plagued by bugs, a never-ending sore.
Saved by the mods, a community's care,
Bethesda's reliance, a cycle unfair.

Ten long years, a relentless parade,
Skyrim's exploitation, a dubious trade.
Squeezing it dry, on each platform it sails,
A superficial effort, as ambition fails.

Worked on with haste, for profit's embrace,
Cashing in on the community's grace.
A model askew, cannot be endorsed,
Skyrim's legacy tarnished, forever enforced.
