Best Game in the History of video Games

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, released in 2011 by Bethesda Game Studios, is an iconic open-world fantasy RPG that has left an indelible mark on the gaming industry. Set in the vast, breathtaking province of Skyrim, this game invites players to immerse themselves in a rich and expansive world filled with dragons, magic, and intrigue. As a devoted fan who has spent countless hours exploring the land of Skyrim, I'm excited to share my detailed review of this epic fantasy adventure.

Gameplay (10/10):
Skyrim sets a new standard for open-world RPGs with its dynamic gameplay and immersive world. The game offers an unprecedented degree of freedom, allowing players to choose their path, be it as a noble warrior, stealthy rogue, or powerful mage. The intuitive leveling system and perk tree enable diverse character customization, ensuring that no two playthroughs are the same. Combat is satisfying and fluid, while the addition of dragon encounters adds thrilling, epic battles to the mix. The radiant quest system ensures that there's always something new to discover, making Skyrim a game that can be played for hundreds of hours.

Storytelling (9/10):
Skyrim's main narrative, centered around the return of dragons to the world, serves as a solid backdrop to the game's exploration and player-driven storytelling. The true strength of Skyrim's storytelling lies in its side quests, which are often as engaging, if not more so, than the main questline. The world is teeming with fascinating characters, each with their own stories and quests, creating a sense of immersion rarely seen in gaming.

Character Development (9/10):
The character development in Skyrim is deeply satisfying. The freedom to shape your character's skills and abilities as you see fit, combined with the vast number of available quests and factions to join, provides an unparalleled sense of agency. The game's numerous companions offer unique personalities and stories, and the modding community has expanded character customization options even further, making it possible to create truly unique adventures.

Graphics and Sound (9/10):
Skyrim's visuals, while showing their age by modern standards, are nonetheless enchanting. The game's art direction creates a stunning, atmospheric world that feels alive. The iconic soundtrack, composed by Jeremy Soule, adds to the sense of immersion, with sweeping melodies that evoke the grandeur of the Elder Scrolls universe.

Skyrim's influence on the gaming industry is undeniable. It set a new bar for open-world RPGs, inspiring countless other developers to create vast, immersive game worlds. The game's modding community has contributed to its longevity, with player-created content extending the game's lifespan and showcasing the power of player-driven creativity.

My personal journey in Skyrim has been a remarkable one. From slaying dragons atop towering mountains to unraveling the mysteries of the Dark Brotherhood, each playthrough has offered a new and captivating adventure. The game's modding community has allowed me to continually revisit and reshape the world of Skyrim, ensuring that the game remains a beloved part of my gaming library.

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a monumental achievement in the RPG genre, offering a rich, immersive world filled with endless adventures. Its expansive gameplay, compelling storytelling, and character development options make it a timeless classic that continues to captivate gamers of all ages. Skyrim's enduring legacy is a testament to its impact on the industry and its ability to transport players to a world of epic fantasy and adventure.

Play, play, play. You can play for hours on end, spend entire days playing this masterpiece, but at the end of each day: Nothing will have changed. You can't finish the game. The amount of marvellous side missions that were in many points, more interesting than the actual story line of the main game, is unending. In RPG games such as this one, I usually do not linger around and try to play side missions, I just like to get the story straight up and finish the main story just to be satisfied with myself... And yet, this game has impressed me over my expectations with how good both the side missions and main missions that it has. 

Skyrim must be enjoyed to the fullest, doing every quest you can, travelling by foot or horse as much as possible, exploring the lands and climbing up mountains and cliff-sides you weren't meant to; That is the truest and fullest beauty of Skyrim. Despite being a single player game, it is unfathomable how much of an experience it is to just take some time from doing anything at all and just... Look around.

[i]Bethesda Pictures presents...[/i]
[h1]Nine Provinces, One Planet[/h1]
[h2]Mysteries of Tamriel: Skyrim[/h2]
[h3]Episode 1: The Skyrim Horse[/h3]
[i]Narrated by David Attenborough. Forward by ChatGPT.[/i]

[Opening scene: A sweeping aerial view of the majestic land of Skyrim, with its towering mountains and lush forests. The camera slowly zooms in on a solitary horse grazing peacefully in a meadow.]

David Attenborough: "In the ancient land of Skyrim, a land filled with wonders and mysteries, there exists a creature that defies all known laws of physics - the Skyrim horse. These hardy creatures roam the vast and treacherous landscapes of this enchanted realm, seemingly impervious to the forces of nature."

[Cut to a close-up of the Skyrim horse, a magnificent steed with a sleek black coat and a wild, untamed mane.]

David Attenborough: "Our story begins with this remarkable creature, a true marvel of nature. To the untrained eye, it may appear as just an ordinary horse, but in reality, it is a master of defying gravity and the laws of physics."

[Camera pans to the horse suddenly launching itself into the air, soaring high above the treetops.]

David Attenborough: "Behold the Skyrim horse in its natural habitat, a realm where gravity is but a mere suggestion. It is said that these creatures have evolved to adapt to the harsh conditions of this land, and in doing so, they have developed a unique ability – the power to defy gravity with every bound."

[Cut to a montage of the horse performing a series of gravity-defying stunts: leaping off cliffs, running up vertical mountainsides, and even walking on air.]

David Attenborough: "Here, we witness the Skyrim horse leaping off a precipice with grace and ease. It is as though the laws of gravity hold no sway over this magnificent beast."

[The camera follows the horse as it charges up the side of a mountain, effortlessly scaling sheer cliffs and defying the laws of friction.]

David Attenborough: "No obstacle is too great for the Skyrim horse. With sheer determination, it can conquer the steepest slopes, scaling cliffs that would send any other creature tumbling to its doom."

[Cut to the horse walking on the surface of a lake, its hooves barely making a ripple on the water.]

David Attenborough: "And here, the Skyrim horse walks upon the very waters themselves, as if it possesses the divine power of walking on air. Its defiance of the laws of buoyancy is nothing short of extraordinary."

[The camera pans to a group of awe-struck Nords watching the horse in amazement.]

David Attenborough: "Even the hardy people of Skyrim, known for their resilience in the face of adversity, are left in awe of this miraculous creature. They have woven tales of the Skyrim horse's feats, believing it to be a symbol of the land's mystical enchantment."

[Cut to the horse, now back on solid ground, galloping at breathtaking speeds through the dense forest.]

David Attenborough: "But while the Skyrim horse's ability to defy the laws of physics is a sight to behold, it also serves a crucial purpose in this unforgiving land. It allows these creatures to navigate treacherous terrain with unparalleled agility, ensuring their survival in the wilds of Skyrim."

[The camera follows the horse as it disappears into the dense forest, leaving only the sound of its hooves echoing through the ancient woods.]

David Attenborough: "And so, the Skyrim horse, a true enigma of nature, continues to thrive in its mystical homeland, where it defies the laws of physics and captures the hearts and imaginations of all who are fortunate enough to witness its extraordinary abilities."

[Closing scene: The Skyrim horse disappears into the forest, and the camera pans up to the vast, endless sky.]

David Attenborough: "In Skyrim, where magic and mystery are woven into the very fabric of the land, the Skyrim horse stands as a testament to the wonders of the natural world. It is a living legend, a creature that reminds us that in the wilds of this world, there are still mysteries waiting to be uncovered and marvels waiting to be admired."

[Fade out as the camera continues to focus on the boundless sky above, highlighting the mystical aura of Skyrim.]

I'm going to be honest, I'm not the biggest fan of this game, especially in comparison to it's predecessors. The things I enjoyed the most from the previous titles have been removed for "streamlining" purposes (Spellcrafting, fun skills like Acrobatics, detailed item enchantment, levitation and feather spells etc.). The good news is you can mod some of it back in, which I highly recommend. The world is big and looks great, love the concept of dragons and certain enemy designs within the world. Unfortunately a lot of the quests play out the same and it gets repetitive fast. At a certain point, it begins to feel like a slog.  I attempted to play through this a fourth time for this review and unfortunately just could not do it again. Succinctly, I do recommend this game if you haven't played it or any of the Elder Scrolls yet. More than worth it on sale with many mods to add features.
mid tbh

The community-generated content keeps this game playable over a decade after release. The incorporation of community-made mods keep the game new and fun for a long time. 

That being said, in some regards it is sad that Bethesda gets away with neglecting to patch their own game while relying on community-made mods to fix basic issues such as gameplay-related or visual glitches in the game. A lot of community-resources get directed towards making the basic game function as its meant to rather than being able to add on to the game in new ways. With the addition of community-generated content as DLC requiring micro-transaction spending, it would be nice if Bethesda could at least keep up with patching out bugs, etc, rather than relying on players needing to explore community-made patches to have the basic game as fully functional.

Even without DLC, community-made mods enable so much extra content that it's questionable whether the DLC is even necessary to really enjoy the game.

The fact I have been playing this game for over 10 years and still find new things... One of the best games ever made. I think we can all remember the first time we picked up this game, we were blown away, the amount of detail, the things you could do, places you could see, for 2011 it was mind blowing and for 2023 its... well still mind blowing! I am someone who doesnt play fantasy games at all, with Skyrim and the other elder scrolls games being the only exception, I think thats really saying something. The way it draws you in with its stunning visuals, heart melting soundtrack, Its just beautiful theres no other word for it. When I play this 'game' I am fully immersed in a way literally no other game has even come close to replicating. I feel this sense of belonging in this world and this sense that I can do anything and be whoever I want. Its so... Homely. Skyrim somehow literally (and I know this sounds weird) makes me think of my own mortality and makes me fear death less. Its hard to explain but something about this... Its just home and if you play it long enough you get this connection that will last for eternity. Seriously If you still somehow havent played this game you owe it to yourself. Give it a try and I promise you will become lost in this world in a great way!

The first time I played Skyrim years ago on my Dad's Xbox 360 I created my character, survived the dragon attack and left to travel the world. One of the more impactful early encounters for me was finding a giant's encampment. I got too close, a group of them would chase me away. I remember the rush I felt. Thought it was the coolest thing wearing stolen armor, dual wielding swords I found on the ground while I ran away as fast as I could. Ended up hiding in a cave. I was hooked, Throughout most of middle school and all of highschool I'd get my Skyrim fix on a year by year basis. At some point in the year it was just time to play Skyrim again. Whether it was the 360, my Playstation 4, or eventually my pc, I will always remember the times I played Skyrim.

I enjoyed the game pretty much. The earlier TES games were more my style though... more open world and roguelike elements, and you could ignore the story entirely, or go on non-storyline artifact quests, and the games were endlessly playable. Arena and Daggerfall. Sure it was the 90s so all the trees looked the same, and there were only so many possible randomized villagers. Newer games (well... relatively newer) are pretty and crafted, but they lose the size, the wandering, and the emergent depth of some of their predecessor games. I guess that's what the market wants. Here you're given a story to follow, but I personally prefer the more sandbox approach where I do what I do and that becomes its own story.

Thoughts after 100% completion (Only late game conclusions):
Recommend mods for:

- magic balance overhaul and more spells
- level cap unlock/higher level cap
- Learning unique item bufffs
- More mage robes

Pros:
- Some quest leave you with unique buffs that are very nice to have
- Great story even in sidequests 
- Lots of hidden subquests and activities
- late in game even basic dungeons get better enemies so it stays a challenge 
Cons:
- late game complementary quests can be extremly grindy
- magic system needs mods to be use it's full potential, otherwise it is lackluster (more damage with levels and quicker heals)
- armor is easy to max out as a mage or with smithing with cap on 550~ or so, best invest in max health and magic resistance at that point
- building a house is the most not-worth-your-time activity in the world, just get a mod for one of the basic houses
- "God-tier" armor obsolete by the time you get it because you can make it 500% better and can't get it's effects
ugh... Just see my remaster review...

Probably the epitome of "open world syndrome". Games that have no business having a large-scale open world getting one, and the entirety of it is an empty, unrewarding, linear mess. No complex movement mechanics to be had here. It shocks me it took until Breath of the Wild and Elden Ring to actually have proper mechanics for scaling open worlds somewhat vertically. A lot of the games map feels deliberately designed to guide players along a path for the sake of story and lore. 

This isn't always a bad thing if the story is actually good, but that is not the case with Skyrim. I never have played a game that is so full of lore and discovery that feels so barren, soulless, and uninspired. It's just textbook Eurofantasy with no semblance of real emotion or tension. It just feels like I'm watching a story unfold before me, and nothing matters. It just feels like a product of its time, and I don't really understand how anyone can view this game as even close to good. It feels plagued by nostalgia and the fact that open world games were somehow much worse than this generally before. This was many gamers first experience with an open world, and it displays just about everything wrong with them. 

The combat mechanics are so bad too. They just feel like Runescape levels of depth, and that game is free to play, and targeted more towards children, so of course it will be somewhat simplistic. The simplicity of this game isn't even satisfying in any way. I just feel like fights are won by me swinging my weapons the same way over and over again until something dies. There's no fun in it, no strategy, and no real purpose as a result. I tried several builds across several different platforms, and no avail. I have tried so hard to appreciate this game, and all attempts have failed. Other Bethesda games suffer from this problem, but at least in games like Fallout, some weapons do have special mechanics such as knockdown or increased knockback or swing speed. Most things in this game barely have any semblance of that. 

Overall this has nothing going for it, but the nostalgia of it being babies first open world game. It is still shocking to me that we really did not get a truly deserving open world experience until Elden Ring; where exploring things actually reward people with unique armor sets or weapons that function in a variety of different satisfying ways; to where there's something in it for everyone, and sometimes those things are not able to be used with the character you made; which makes you want to play the game again. Skyrim has none of this. You sit through an excessively boring story, deal with unsatisfying discovery, and are rewarded with the most boring final boss I've ever had to sit through in a game. Wow; the dragon functions exactly like every other dragon in the game!!! Flies around and you can't deal with it until it lands and then you just walk up to it and fight it like literally every other enemy in the game. So satisfying! What a conclusion to such a shit game. At least it fits the vibe of the game being a boring slog I guess. 

I do not see the appeal for this game. I never will see the appeal for this game. It's the most soulless, uninspired, underdeveloped AAA game I have ever played. I don't think anything will come close to topping how boring and pointless this game is.

I work in the Tourism field, more spesificly hotel, and i want to tell a story. Now you might think what can possibly be tourism and skyrim have to do with each other. 

We had a guest came to the hotel i work in and he was going to stay here for a while. He was ordering food from outside all the time and we was just saying hi  to each other when he comes in for picking up his order. Me as someone who's curious i always talk to guests and ask what they are doing,who they are what they do for a living etc. but this guy was a bit shy and kind of discrete. One evening after a while he's stayed in the hotel, another food delivery came in for him. And when he came to pick it up i told him how he is and some small talk. I asked him what was he doing for a living he merely answered '' i am just someone who likes to play games '' but i knew that wasn't the case and told him jokingly naah you're joking with me. And at that time he said no! I even got a tatto from my favourite game. And after that slowly pulled his sleeve up and show me tatto he's got expecting me to not know anything about it. It was the logo of the Skyrim and was my pc background in the past. The moment i saw his tatto, my eyes got lighten up and passionately told him thats skyrim! He wasn't expecting me to recognize it or played the game at all but as you can imagine that wasn't case. After my recognition of his skyrim tattoo that shy, discrete guy went off and a new guy with a big smile and easy to talk came in. And we have had great conversation about games,future, and life untill our conversation was interrupted by some other guest. 

It was thanks to this game i could bond with someone whom they thought that we did not have anything in common. Different cultural backgrounds different proffessions different languages and different life styles until two dudes has nothing in common found out they were huge fans of the same game. That's the proof of power of Skyrim.Sad thing is this whole discovery was happened at his last day. And we couldn't exchange communications. 

So. Mr. R if you happen to see this comment reach me out and we can continue our converstaion. Cheers!

Skyrim - An Endless Journey

After spending over 300 hours in the realm of Skyrim, I can confidently say that this game has left an indelible mark on me. I've slain dragons, uncovered hidden tombs, and forged epic legends. Yet, what continues to amaze me is how I still find joy in the simple act of strolling through the enchanting forests of this magical world. 

Skyrim's ability to keep me enchanted, even after completing countless quests and mastering various skills, is a testament to its enduring appeal. It's a game that rewards both the thrill of epic adventures and the tranquility of quiet moments in nature. 

So, with utmost conviction, I give Skyrim a solid 10/10. It's a masterpiece that keeps on giving, and I look forward to many more hours of exploration and wonder.

Led by the beacon of meridia he has chosen to become a priest of the catholic church and will hopefully do very good things for them. All in all a lifetime of amazing moments brought on by this game, sure we may of gotten into mischief at one point in time or another, but throughout the world lots of people do many things that are equally as horrible as us. This game taught us to live in the now, and to not worry about the next big thing to come about. Hot take: I don't like Skyrim. I got into gaming late and didn't experience it when it came out and was supposed to be a technical marvel. I don't have any nostalgia. 

Trying to play it years later, I expected a good game based on the hype and good reviews. I don't think it is one. And I don't think it's just because it's old, DA Origins or Mass Effect came out earlier and are great games even today. 

Some of my issues:
- The world may be big, but it's empty and repetitive. I don't feel it's worthy of exploration, and exploration is like the only thing this game has to offer.
- The combat is awkward and clunky. 
- Most quests are surface level repetitive fetch quests and chores that I don't care about.
- The writing is non existent. The NPCs are just there. They don't really do anything, they are just decoration. I literally don't care about a single one. Good characters and companions with their own stories is my favourite thing in RPGs. And it's a pity it's not present here. 
- On the same note, is it even an RPG if you don't have any choices and what you do doesn't matter at all? Your only choice is where you go and which quests you do, but if you do them you just do them them the one way you can. 
- The bugs are a feature at this point and were honestly the funniest and most enjoyable part of the game. And that is depressing.

Honestly I'm not sure what to do in this game. Unless you have a Thomas the tank engine characters mod or the AI companion that roast you all the time, the game is just incredibly shallow and boring. The only enjoyment I can see people having in Skyrim is modding it to the max and seeing how many cheese wheels you can drop in until the game crashes. I see the value of streamers doing the most unhinged stuff for entertainment. 

 But actually playing vanilla Skyrim? Not so much.

My The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim review

The positives

+The best gaming world of any game ever, one that is also beautiful and feels alive
+Diverse builds
+Really replayable
+A ridiculous amount of content, although not all of it is very well made
+Fantastic mods
+The best gameplay mechanics of any game, ever
+Unbelievably good soundtrack
+Second best exploration of any game ever, only surpassed by Elden Ring
+Lots of diverse activities
+Excellent level design in some places, almost FromSoftware level
+Great progression
+Amazing atmosphere
+Very immersive
+Fantastic DLCs

The negatives

-Combat is very lacking and boring with almost all builds
-The main story is way too short
-Animations are very lacking, though that's more acceptable for a 2011 game
-The voice acting is mostly below average and the sheer amount of recycled voice actors only adds to this issue
-The game is still very buggy
-Too many mindless fetch quests
-Movement is pretty bad
-AI is absolute garbage
-The world feels too small and the cities feel underwhelming. The cities are small in size and there are too few inhabitants
-The shouts are not very interesting to use due to their cooldowns, which makes them bad rewards from exploration
-The money system doesn't work very well

Score: 9.2/10

An Epic Adventure Awaits, Thanks to Skyrim!

If you're a true Skyrim lover like myself, you'll understand the sheer magic that this game has to offer. Skyrim isn't just a game; it's an immersive journey that transports you to a world filled with breathtaking landscapes, intricate lore, and endless opportunities for exploration.

From the moment you step foot in the rugged and diverse province of Skyrim, you're greeted by an open world that feels alive with its bustling cities, tranquil forests, towering mountains, and mysterious ruins. The attention to detail is simply astounding, with each location meticulously crafted to draw you in and make you feel like a part of this fantastical realm.

But it's not just the environment that makes Skyrim exceptional – it's the rich history and compelling stories that weave throughout the land. The depth of the lore is truly impressive, and every NPC you meet has a unique tale to tell. Whether you're unraveling the enigma of the Dragonborn, delving into the political intrigue of various factions, or simply embarking on side quests that seem almost as important as the main story, you're constantly engaged and invested in the world around you.

And let's not forget the exhilarating combat! Whether you're wielding a sword, casting powerful spells, or sneaking your way through the shadows as an agile thief, the combat mechanics offer satisfying and varied gameplay. Plus, the ability to customize your character's skills and playstyle ensures that no two adventures are ever the same.

Skyrim's longevity is also a testament to its exceptional modding community. The sheer creativity and dedication of modders have brought even more life to the game, with thousands of mods adding everything from new quests and characters to enhanced graphics and gameplay mechanics. This means that, even after countless hours, there's always something new to discover and experience.

In conclusion, Skyrim isn't just a game; it's an ongoing love affair for anyone who appreciates the art of storytelling, exploration, and epic fantasy. It's a masterpiece that continues to capture the hearts of gamers around the world, and if you're a true Skyrim lover, you'll find yourself returning to its enchanting world time and time again.

Ralof: "Hey, you. You're finally awake. You were trying to cross the border, right? Walked right into that Imperial ambush, same as us, and that thief over there."
Lokir: "Damn you Stormcloaks. Skyrim was fine until you came along. Empire was nice and lazy. If they hadn't been looking for you, I could've stolen that horse and been halfway to Hammerfell. You there... You and me, we shouldn't be here. It's these Stormcloaks the Empire wants."
Ralof: "We're all brothers and sisters in binds now, thief."
Imperial Soldier: "Shut up back there!"
Lokir: "And what's wrong with him, huh?"
Ralof: "Watch your tongue. You're speaking to Ulfric Stormcloak, the true High King."
Lokir: "Ulfric? The Jarl of Windhelm? You're the leader of the rebellion. But if they've captured you... Oh gods, where are they taking us?"
Ralof: "I don't know where we're going, but Sovngarde awaits."
Lokir: "No, this can't be happening. This isn't happening."
Ralof: "Hey, what village are you from, horse thief?"
Lokir: "Why do you care?"
Ralof: "A Nord's last thoughts should be of home."
Lokir: "Rorikstead. I'm... I'm from Rorikstead."
Imperial: "General Tullius, sir! The headsman is waiting!"
Tullius: "Good. Let's get this over with."
Lokir: "Shor, Mara, Dibella, Kynareth, Akatosh. Divines, please help me."
Ralof: "Look at him, General Tullius, the Military Governor. And it looks like the Thalmor are with him. Damn elves. I bet they had something to do with this. This is Helgen. I used to be sweet on a girl from here. Wonder if Vilod is still making that mead with juniper berries mixed in. Funny, when I was a boy, Imperial walls and towers used to make me feel so safe."
Haming: "Who are they, daddy? Where are they going?"
Torolf: "You need to go inside, little cub."
Haming: "Why? I want to watch the soldiers."
Torolf: "Inside the house. Now."
Haming: "Yes, papa."
Imperial: "Whoa!"
Captain: "Get these prisoners out of the carts. Move it!"
Lokir: "Why are we stopping?"
Ralof: "Why do you think? End of the line. Let's go. Shouldn't keep the gods waiting for us."
Lokir: "No! Wait! We're not rebels!"
Ralof: "Face your death with some courage, thief."
Lokir: "You've got to tell them! We weren't with you! This is a mistake!"
Imperial Captain: "Step towards the block when we call your name. One at a time."
Ralof: "Empire loves their damn lists."
Hadvar: "Ulfric Stormcloak. Jarl of Windhelm."
Ralof: "It has been an honor, Jarl Ulfric!"
Hadvar: "Ralof of Riverwood. Lokir of Rorikstead."
Lokir: "No, I'm not a rebel. You can't do this!"
Captain: "Halt!"
Lokir: "You're not going to kill me!"
Captain: "Archers!"
Captain: "Anyone else feel like running?"
Hadvar: "Wait. You there. Step forward. Who are you?"

I have been playing this game since the 360. I have bought it no less than 3 times. I have played it across 4 separate platforms, 
Only today, in 2023, have I finished a single play-through with every main story and side story completion, from both the base game and the DLC. Only today have I gained all Steam achievements and beaten the two optional endgame boss fights. 
On Steam I have 477 hours, but I likely have over 1000 across every platform. I have 105 mods on my current game, and i consider that a light amount.
Is this game perfect? No, not at all, I have developed a nervous reflex of pressing F5 to quick-save before anything that could crash my game. Is this game pretty? for 2013, yes, by modern standards it feels a little washed out. Is it the best Elder Scrolls game? i can't say for sure, i haven't played them all. But is this game worth playing? Without question.
Play Skyrim.

This installment of the Elder Scrolls series presents a wide range of varied and complex game mechanics in a simple and digestible way. This game is extremely accessible to players that have little to no experience or interest in complex RPG game elements.The story is captivating and is one of the few games I've completed more than five times and will probably revisit again soon. The largest factor of this insane replayability at least for me is the absolutely massive library of mods that are available online. The community of modders for this game is one of if not the strongest, largest and most outgoing I've ever seen. This game is truly special, and if you haven't played it yet, you owe it to yourself to give it a try.

I have spent more than 1000 hours on this game, and im still playing it.
Sometimes, i`m just making whole new games, without DLC`s, clearing the whole map again and again, playing different styles like sneaky archer, heavy armored tank or shout/magic combined wizard.
Spending many hours on gathering the materials from the wilderness and vendors in the city does not make my game bored.
And of course, there are some times, when i just want to destroy the whole world with console commands. Raining multiple Alduin on Whiterun is my favorite.
With Skyrim creation kit, i can "balance" game settings to the way i enjoy it, because some of the "numbers" that are set in stone by Bethesda is not the best. Tweaking the game with the Creation Kit is always fun :)
The base version of the game is still better than the "new", so called "legendary" one. I can decided, which DLC is on, and which one is off.
Man, this game brings me back, so many good memories.

Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle. 
Skyrim is a game with a whole lot, but not much thought involved. Follow arrow. Kill thing. Follow arrow. Go through dungeon. Kill thing. Take loot. Repeat. You are ALWAYS the Dragonborn, and will always do the same things your last character did (at least if you're playing the main story). Because the class and skill system has been reduced to a extremely simple 'perk' system, you can play it damn near however you'd like, whenever you'd like. But it just doesn't make for a terribly engaging experience, especially after you've played through the story once. If you can stand the old look and feel, I'd try TES III Morrowind if you're looking for a proper RPG experience. This is more of a fantasy action/adventure game.

to be honest despite everything i still kind of love skyrim and it also kind of helped me to get through the dark times,
because its unique yet kind of familiar world, that filled with medieval, phantasy, magical atmosphere vibes got me drowned in it.
i've been wasting too many hours on real life, but i tried my best to spend as much of it as possible on millions of quests like saving towns from a dragons, building manors and clearing dungeons full of undead or a reclusive cannibal cults...
buying and selling stuff, smithing armors and weapons without claiming to be the best blacksmith in whiterun, enchanting items using souls of defeated foes or annoying characters like nazeem, learning the art of war by dodging arrows in the knees, learning magical skills and spells by burning innocent goats and deers, learning alchemy by eating and mixing random sh*t, sneaking through the shadows, stealing people's clothes and booze, lockpicking houses and chests, searching for a daedric artifacts, shouting my way through the followers, dying from falling out of the mountains while trying to find shortcuts, farming and cooking,  talking to a doors or a trees or a dogs and such, taming bloody dragons, shouting as you've never shout before and many many more billions of things...
yet no matter how many years i've spend on endless adventures and countless, though unique characters, most of which i can't even remember, skyrim can still surprise me and show something new or make me laugh once again...



my overall thoughts:

i know that it is quite far from being a perfect game, but it just gave me too many emotions and experiences, after which it is undoubtedly deserves a special place in my heart < 3

Introduction:
Skyrim, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, is an epic role-playing game that takes players on an immersive journey through the vast and breathtaking land of Tamriel. Released in 2011, Skyrim has become a benchmark for open-world RPGs, offering a rich and engaging gameplay experience filled with captivating quests, expansive landscapes, and a deep lore that draws players into its fantastical world. In this review, we will explore the many facets that make Skyrim a timeless masterpiece in the realm of video games.

Gameplay:
Skyrim presents a seamless blend of exploration, combat, and character development. As the Dragonborn, a legendary hero with the power to harness the language of dragons, players embark on a quest to save the realm from an ancient evil. The game's open-world environment allows for unparalleled freedom, enabling players to tackle quests in any order and make impactful choices that shape their character's story.

Vast and Immersive World:
The province of Skyrim serves as the game's primary setting, and it is a marvel to behold. From snowy mountains to dense forests and sprawling cities, each location in Skyrim is meticulously crafted with breathtaking attention to detail. Exploring its diverse landscapes reveals hidden treasures, ancient ruins, and captivating encounters that make every journey a memorable experience.

Engaging Quests and Intriguing Characters:
Skyrim is replete with an extensive array of quests, ranging from the main storyline to countless side quests that immerse players in the lives and struggles of the people inhabiting Tamriel. The characters encountered throughout the game are varied and memorable, each with their own stories, motivations, and voice acting that breathes life into the world. Whether aiding a political faction, delving into ancient lore, or slaying mythical creatures, the quests in Skyrim are diverse and captivating.

Character Progression and Customization:
Skyrim offers a robust character creation system that allows players to craft their ideal hero or heroine. The game features a flexible class system, enabling players to specialize in various skills such as archery, magic, or stealth. As characters progress, they earn experience points and unlock new abilities, spells, and perks that enhance their playstyle. The freedom to shape your character's skills and abilities provides a sense of ownership and personalization.

Epic Battles and Exciting Combat:
Combat in Skyrim is visceral and engaging, with a range of weapons and spells at the player's disposal. Engaging in battles against fearsome dragons, bandits, and mythical creatures is a thrilling experience. The game strikes a balance between real-time combat and strategic decision-making, allowing players to utilize different tactics based on their preferred playstyle.

Modding Community and Longevity:
One of Skyrim's greatest strengths lies in its modding community. With extensive modding support, players can access an incredible variety of user-created content, including new quests, graphical enhancements, gameplay tweaks, and even complete overhauls of the game. This active modding community has breathed new life into Skyrim, ensuring its longevity and providing players with endless opportunities for exploration and customization.

Conclusion:
Skyrim is a legendary RPG that has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. With its immersive world, captivating quests, memorable characters, and unparalleled freedom, the game offers an unparalleled experience for fans of epic fantasy adventures. Whether you are a seasoned RPG enthusiast or a newcomer to the genre, Skyrim's enchanting world and boundless possibilities will keep you hooked for countless hours of exploration, combat, and discovery.

Let me start by saying that Skyrim is an absolute masterpiece. It is a game that transcends the boundaries of what we thought possible in the realm of open-world RPGs. From the moment you step foot into the vast and breathtaking province of Skyrim, you are transported to a world teeming with life, wonder, and limitless possibilities.

First and foremost, the sheer size and detail of Skyrim's world is mind-boggling. The landscapes are exquisitely crafted, from towering snow-capped mountains to dense forests, sprawling tundras, and ancient ruins. The attention to detail is astonishing, making every nook and cranny of the world feel like it has a story to tell. Exploring this vast realm is a joy in itself, as you stumble upon hidden treasures, encounter unique characters, and uncover captivating lore.

The freedom of choice in Skyrim is unparalleled. You can be whoever you want to be, shaping your destiny as you see fit. Whether you choose to be a valiant knight, a stealthy assassin, a powerful mage, or anything in between, the game allows you to play to your preferred playstyle. The character customization options are extensive, ensuring that your hero is truly your own creation.

The main questline of Skyrim is engrossing, filled with intriguing characters, epic battles, and unexpected twists. The fate of the world hangs in the balance as you navigate political intrigue, ancient prophecies, and the return of fearsome dragons. The writing is top-notch, with memorable dialogue and morally complex choices that truly make you feel invested in the outcome.

Yet, Skyrim's brilliance extends far beyond its main story. The game is overflowing with side quests, guilds, and miscellaneous tasks that immerse you even further into its world. Whether you're joining the secretive Thieves Guild, becoming a member of the warrior-focused Companions, or delving into the enigmatic world of magic at the College of Winterhold, there's always something new and exciting to discover.

The combat in Skyrim is satisfyingly dynamic. Whether you prefer close-quarters melee combat, ranged archery, or unleashing devastating spells, the game caters to your preferred style. Engaging in battles with ferocious creatures and bandits feels intense, and the variety of weapons and magical abilities at your disposal keep the combat fresh and exciting throughout your adventure.

What truly sets Skyrim apart, however, is its modding community. The game's flexibility and mod support have given rise to an astonishing array of user-created content that enhances and expands the experience in countless ways. From graphical improvements to gameplay tweaks, new quests, and even entirely new lands to explore, the mods breathe new life into the game, ensuring that you'll never run out of things to do.

Finally, the hauntingly beautiful score and atmospheric sound design elevate Skyrim to another level of immersion. The sweeping orchestral compositions perfectly capture the grandeur of the world, while the ambient sounds of nature and bustling towns breathe life into the game's environments.

In conclusion, Skyrim is a gaming experience that will stay with you long after you've set down the controller. Its vast and richly detailed world, compelling quests, freedom of choice, and the unwavering dedication of its modding community make it a game that stands the test of time. Whether you're a veteran RPG player or new to the genre, Skyrim is an absolute must-play that will leave you longing for more adventures in its mesmerizing realm.

This is one of my favourite games of all time. While some aspects of the gameplay may lack in depth, such as the lacklustre combat or simplistic skill and perk system, the game makes up for this and then some with a sheer size that to this day I have never seen replicated by any company other than Bethesda Softworks. There is just so much in the world to do and see. Your quest journal will be clogged up with a million different sidequests, each of which has a genuinely interesting story to tell. From investigating murders to investigating covens of cannibals, from fighting pirates to entering a drinking competition with a god, all the way to fighting an entire civil war, changing the fate of the province forever, Skyrim has no shortage of things to do, and this is without even considering the amazing work of talented modders that keeps new content coming on a daily basis to this decade-old game. It's a game world that makes you want to explore it, and rewards your efforts at every step of the way. If you like fantasy or the RPG genre, you absolutely must play this game at some point in your life, and the best time is now. Get this game - you won't regret it.

Do not mind the review let me write an essay on Nazeem.


Nazeem, the infamous NPC from the popular video game Skyrim, has become a subject of both memes and community discussions since the game's release in 2011. Though his character may seem unremarkable at first glance, his boastful and condescending attitude has made him a target for humorous mockery and lively debates among players.
Nazeem, a resident of the town of Whiterun, is known for his oft-repeated line: "Do you get to the Cloud District very often? Oh, what am I saying? Of course, you don't." This seemingly innocuous comment has gained notoriety and has been widely memed and parodied by the Skyrim community.
The line's ubiquity in the gaming community has led to countless humorous variations and remixes. Memes featuring Nazeem often include references to the Cloud District and sarcastic responses from other characters or players, highlighting the repetitive nature of his dialogue. These memes have become a way for players to bond over their shared experiences and frustrations with Nazeem's self-important attitude.
In addition to the memes, discussions about Nazeem have flourished within the Skyrim community. Some players find his character irritating, often going out of their way to avoid interactions with him. On the other hand, some players find him amusing and enjoy engaging with his haughty demeanor. These conflicting opinions have sparked debates on forums and social media platforms, further fueling the fascination surrounding Nazeem.
Beyond his meme-worthy status, Nazeem's presence in Skyrim reflects the game's commitment to creating a diverse cast of characters, each with their own quirks and personalities. The fact that a relatively minor NPC like Nazeem has garnered such attention and spawned a community-driven phenomenon speaks to the depth and impact of Skyrim's world-building.
In conclusion, Nazeem, the self-important resident of Whiterun, has become an iconic figure within the Skyrim community. Through his memorable dialogue and divisive personality, he has inspired countless memes, sparked debates, and become a symbol of both frustration and amusement for players. Whether you love him or find him exasperating, there's no denying that Nazeem has left an indelible mark on the Skyrim experience. So, the next time you visit the Cloud District, remember to savor the jokes and discussions surrounding this enduring character.

No one will ever read this but I recommend this game

- Found my soulmate (might be a werewolf, jury's still out on that one)
- Became the adoptive parent of a tiny army (seriously, I can't remember all their names)
- Threw together a luxury estate (though, I'm pretty sure there are still draugr in the basement)
- Started a canine refuge (just call me the Dog Whisperer of Whiterun)
- Discovered I'm the Nord reincarnation of God (no big deal or anything)
- Turned my divine 'whisper' into the dragon equivalent of a roach spray (they really hate it when you Shout at them)
- Mastered the culinary arts (who knew Giant's Toes and Skeever Tails were so gourmet?)
- Became a vampire, cured myself, then became a werewolf (it's been a wild week)
- Subscribed to the "Sword in the Face" school of conflict resolution (diplomacy, what's that?)
- Explored every dark, cobweb-filled dungeon (surely the next one won't be full of undead)
- Turned into a kleptomaniac for sweet rolls (I swear it's for a quest)
- Took on the Jarl's responsibilities (pro tip: always let Lydia handle the paperwork)
- Engaged in the world's most intense staring contests with dragons (Dovahkiin? More like Dovah-kin-optometrist!)
- Became a professional butterfly catcher (the pay is awful, but the job satisfaction is unbeatable)
- Killed a chicken, sparked a civil war (those Nords sure love their poultry)
- Carved a career as a home decorator (all those troll skulls aren't going to display themselves)
- Woke up from a wild night in Markarth with a Daedric Prince (note to self: no more mead challenges with Sam Guevenne)
- Almost became an unwilling sacrifice to Boethiah (oops, read the job description next time)
- Developed a knack for befriending eldritch horrors (Hermaeus Mora sends his best regards)
- Died more times to random frost trolls than the World-Eater (so much for being the Dragonborn)
- Invented a new sport: Sabre Cat rodeo (the key is to not let go)
- Realized that becoming Thane is just a gateway drug to hoarding decorative weaponry
- Mastered the art of shouting people off cliffs (I guess that's one way to avoid small talk)
- Caused an extinction event for the local mudcrab population (sorry, PETA)
- Perfected my archery skills on the ever-elusive "knee target" (I used to be an adventurer like you...)
- Discovered that a life of crime pays (until you try to sell stolen goods back to their original owner)
- Became a part-time bard (still working on that "Ragnar the Red" cover)
- Made a hobby of collecting dangerous Daedric artifacts (who needs safety when you have unlimited power?)
- Started a fashion trend in Whiterun with my exquisite Fur Armor couture
- Accidentally caused a mammoth stampede (Fus Ro Dah does not translate to "gentle persuasion")
- Got a horse that defies gravity (Shadowmere's mountain climbing skills are top notch)
- Invested heavily in cheese wheels (they're the future of Tamriel's economy, I tell you)
- Became a certified dragon dentist (all those Dragon Shouts really do a number on their oral hygiene)
- Found a glitch in the matrix (why do guards keep talking about their sweetroll theft trauma?)
- Took a casual swim in the Sea of Ghosts (spoiler: it's just really, really cold)
- Turned every single ruin into my personal undead extermination playground (take that, Draugr)
- Successfully played hide-and-seek with an Elder Scroll (I swear, I left it right here!)
- Managed to master the lost art of "arrow to the knee" joke-telling (they never get old, right?)
- Ventured into stealth-archery (because why fight fair when you can one-shot enemies from the shadows?)
- Learned to speak Dragon fluently (still working on the accent though)
- Unintentionally started a Nirnroot farm (those things glow brighter than my future)
- Single-handedly increased Skyrim's mead consumption (Honningbrew, if you're listening, I'll take a sponsorship)
- Became an unlicensed pharmacist (all those questionable potions have to go somewhere, right?)
- Perfected my Fus-Ro-Dah-powered home run (who knew giants could fly that high?)
- Kept finding mysterious "Notched Pickaxes" (does anyone know a blacksmith named 'Steve'?)
- Opened a therapy clinic for giants with post-traumatic adventurer syndrome (you'd be surprised how many suffer from it)
- Accidentally released a notorious evil dragon from an ancient seal (oops... my bad, sorry Skyrim)
- Played matchmaker for an entire town (Riften has never been so lively... or awkward)
- Got lost in an alternate universe (also known as Apocrypha - 0/10, would not recommend, the tentacles are not friendly)
- Started a mammoth tipping business (tip: they tip back... hard)
- Became a shout DJ at the local tavern (beat-dropping Fus Ro Dah is a crowd pleaser)
- Got a pet dragon (he's a good boy, just a bit fiery)
- Made it on the Thalmor's most wanted list (finally, my actions are getting the recognition they deserve)
- Became an amateur entomologist (who knew torchbugs were so fascinating?)
- Beat the Ebony Warrior at arm wrestling (that one took a few reloads, not gonna lie)
- Entered Sovngarde and came back just for the fun of it (travel reviews: 4/5 stars, needs more living people)
- Single-handedly decimated Skyrim's cabbage stocks (I blame my horse's voracious appetite)
- Started a support group for people who can't fast travel because enemies are nearby (we meet on Tuesdays)

This is a good game. I have played it on Xbox when it came out in 2011 and I still play to this day. It's not perfect, it's simple and it definitely has simplistic mechanics compared to the previous games but the scenery, overall feeling and modding community makes it one of my favourite games. 

If you plan to heavily mod and don't mind the frequent crashes buy this version of the game, otherwise if you want a more stable and optimized version go for the anniversary edition.

The only scenario where I could see myself recommending this game would be for the Enderal mod, which is a wholely unique game made in Skyrim's engine. I can't bring myself to like this game. I know that it's a touchstone for a lot of gamers - which is fine - but I just can't get invested in this game in the way that so many others have. Plot, characters, leveling, crafting, art direction, combat, BUGS; no amount of mods or rose-tinted glasses can fix how bland and lifeless these things are for me.

I'm going to assume that if you're reading this review, it's because you're new to RPG's in general and have heard good things about Skyrim. If that's the case, then there are so many better places to start. I don't want this review to be a bunch of negativity, so here's what I would recommend:

-Dungeons & Dragons/Pathfinder; Go to your local game store, buy a Player's Handbook and some dice, roll up a character, and join a group. This is absolutely still the best way to get into RPG's and it's the kind of game that you can literally play FOREVER. Plus, if you don't have a local store, there are a couple of different ways to find groups to play with online. Put yourself out there!

-Super Mario RPG/Paper Mario/Mario and Luigi, Superstar Saga; These are all very simple RPG's that still have an engaging amount of depth in their mechanics. They're all charming as heck, and are definitely worth your time. You can find Paper Mario and Mario and Luigi on the Nintendo EShop. As for Super Mario RPG... well lets just say that there are less legal ways of easily acquiring that one these days. [spoiler] ROMS [/spoiler]

-Bug Fables; It's Paper Mario, but it doesn't have any Mario characters. You can find the demo here! https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/bug-fables-an-exploration-rpg-full-of-bugs#/ The full game is also available on Steam.

-Cosmic Star Heroine/Chrono Trigger; Both are great story driven games made in the JRPG mold, with the only real difference between the two being their aesthetics. You can find both of them here on Steam, but if you're going to play Chrono Trigger I would recommend the DS port.

-Literally any Dragon Quest game; They're a bit old-fashioned, but many gamers find the simplicity to be charming and relaxing ( it's like how you'd be hard-pressed to find someone who doesn't like Kirby). The fan favorite is Dragon Quest VIII and you can find Dragon Quest XI here on Steam.

-Path of Exile/Torchlight/Borderlands 2; Diablo may be the game that created the "loot-grind" genre, but these games are definitely holding up the legacy in a much better fashion. Path of Exile and Torchlight are presented in the traditional isometric view while Borderlands 2 is a first-person shooter, with all of these games centered around killing dudes to get lots of weapons so that you can find the one weapon that you actually want... which is much more fun than it sounds. You can find all of them here on Steam, and Path of Exile is even free to play!

-Monster Hunter: Do you want an RPG with fantastic combat? Do you want an RPG you can play with your friends? Do you want to explore a cave-punk fantasy world? Do you not care about villain monologues or saving the world and just want to FITE BEEG MONSTAH? Then you should try out Capcoms' legendary action-RPG series. MH: World and MH: Rise are both available here on Steam, and you can't go wrong with either.

-Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow/Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night/Hollow Knight; Most Metroidvanias would fit on this list, but for my money these are the ones that best combine exploration with stat juggling and reflex-based combat. Hollow Knight and Bloodstained are available here on Steam and all of these games can be found on the Nintendo EShop.

-Fallout New Vegas: Hey, do you want to play a Bethesda game made by people who actually know what they're doing? Look no further than arguably the best game in the Fallout franchise. Check out H.Bomberguy's epic review of the game here for a more complete explanation. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzF7aHxk4Y4

- Tainted Grail: The Fall of Avalon/Dread Delusion; If the only thing that can scratch your itch is a first-person fantasy roleplaying game, then these two might be what your looking for. They're not out *yet*, but both of these games are full of passion and promise. Both are in early access here on Steam if you're curious. https://store.steampowered.com/app/1466060/Tainted_Grail_The_Fall_of_Avalon/ https://store.steampowered.com/app/1574240/Dread_Delusion/

Hopefully I've given anyone interested a decent assortment of titles to choose from. I tried to pick RPG's with easy entry points rather than something more intense (like Dark Souls or Disco Elysium). If you have suggestions for other RPG's that would be great for first-timers, be sure to leave a comment below. Thanks for your time!

The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim, developed by Bethesda Game Studios, is an iconic open-world role-playing game that has left an indelible mark on the gaming landscape. With its vast and breathtaking world, rich lore, immersive gameplay, and boundless exploration, Skyrim stands as a true masterpiece of the fantasy genre.

One of Skyrim's greatest strengths lies in its immersive and beautifully crafted world. The province of Skyrim itself is a sprawling and diverse land, filled with towering mountains, dense forests, ancient ruins, and bustling cities. Each location is meticulously designed, capturing a sense of grandeur and wonder. The attention to detail is astounding, whether it's the awe-inspiring architecture or the subtle environmental effects that bring the world to life.

The game's lore and storytelling are equally impressive. The Elder Scrolls series has always been known for its deep and intricate lore, and Skyrim continues this tradition. The world is steeped in rich history, with numerous books, legends, and factions that add layers of depth and intrigue. The main questline is engaging and filled with memorable characters, but it's the countless side quests and random encounters that truly make Skyrim shine. Each quest feels unique and meaningful, offering glimpses into the lives of the people inhabiting this vast world.

Skyrim's character customization and progression systems are robust and rewarding. From choosing your race and appearance to deciding on a playstyle, the game offers immense freedom and flexibility. Whether you prefer to wield a mighty sword, cast devastating spells, or master stealthy tactics, the game caters to a wide range of playstyles. As you level up, you can invest in various skills, unlocking new abilities and becoming a formidable force in combat.

Speaking of combat, Skyrim strikes a satisfying balance between accessibility and depth. The real-time combat mechanics feel fluid and responsive, allowing you to engage in thrilling battles with a wide array of enemies, including fearsome dragons. The addition of shouts, powerful abilities that you acquire throughout the game, adds an extra layer of strategic depth and spectacle to the combat encounters.

The modding community for Skyrim is legendary, and it greatly extends the game's lifespan. The ability to modify and enhance various aspects of the game, from graphical improvements to new quests and gameplay mechanics, allows players to create their own personalized Skyrim experience. This vibrant modding scene ensures that there's always something new to discover and keeps the game feeling fresh, even years after its initial release.

It's worth noting that Skyrim, despite its numerous strengths, is not without its flaws. Some players have criticized the game for occasional technical issues, graphical glitches, and NPC AI inconsistencies. However, these minor blemishes pale in comparison to the grandeur and depth of the overall experience.

In conclusion, The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a monumental achievement in the world of gaming. Its breathtaking world, rich lore, immersive gameplay, and endless possibilities for exploration and customization make it a truly unforgettable adventure. Whether you're a fan of fantasy RPGs or a newcomer to the genre, Skyrim is a must-play title that will captivate you for countless hours and leave you with memories that will endure long after the game is over.

Well, review for the sake of completion since this version is a [u]DELISTED Bethesda game[/u].. Should probably just update the SE-version.. I have had some genuinely great times with Skyrim, but also some of the wonkiest moments in gaming history. So I have been playing around as a sneaky cat girl slaying humans in a vaguely iron age scandinavian dreamworld where everyone is named Sven.. On my long journey I made friends, killed said friends, slayed some dragons, hanged out with daedras, cooked food, drank mead, became a ranking member of the Thieves Guild, swaggered in the Cloud District and collected truckloads of insectoid eggs beneath a spooky tower..

Did I have a great time? Well, yes.. Kinda..
Was it smooth as silk and without any flaws? Hell no..

Skyrim is one of those weird games. On paper it has tons of story, a completely egalitarian world where everyone is living a dream (until they get the legendary arrow to their kneecap and end up on patrol duty) and a lot of free time to dawdle about. Is the time well spent? Well that is the main question. The combat feels clunky at times, the stealth game is kinda ass, the magic is the worst of the lot and somehow me being the head honcho of both the thieves guild, the dark brotherhood and the mages guild all at once feels a bit, well, weird.. Some choices have little to no consequences, others you can't really fathom until it is to late.

The best thing that has come out of Skyrim in the end is its mutating nature. By now there is almost an internet rule for all the weird things people have modded into this game, so should you fancy it, there is probably a mod for it.. In the end however this is a fine piece of entertainment and I highly recommend it if you like high adventure and sprawling worldbuilding. If you are going to play this game do yourself a favor and AT LEAST download “The Paarthurnax Dilemma”.. Everything else from anime-waifus to improved mudcrab physics is optional, the dilemma is not..

🌟 Review of "TES: Skyrim" 🐉

Oh boy, where do I even start with this game? 🤔🎮 Skyrim is like a magical 🧙‍♂️adventure on steroids! 🏔️ From the moment you step into the world of Skyrim, you're greeted with stunning landscapes that make you want to shout, "Fus Ro Dah!" 🗣️💥

🤷‍♀️ I mean, who needs a social life when you have dragons 🐉 raining fire 🔥 from the sky? And let's not forget about the NPCs! They're so realistic, it's like they have a mind of their own! 🤯 Except for that one time when a guard took an arrow to the knee... 😂🏹

The questlines in Skyrim are as addictive as sweetrolls 🍞🧁, and the possibilities are endless! Whether you want to be a stealthy thief 🦝, a fearless warrior ⚔️, or a powerful mage 🧙‍♀️, Skyrim has got you covered. And if you get bored, just take an arrow in the knee and become a town guard! 🎯🏰

The glitches in Skyrim are practically a feature at this point. 😜 Who needs bug-free gameplay when you can witness a flying mammoth 🐘 or a horse doing acrobatics? 🐴🤸‍♂️ It's like watching Cirque du Soleil in the land of dragons! 🎪🐉

But you know what? Despite the occasional wonky moments, Skyrim has a special place in my heart ❤️. It's a game that can make you laugh, cry, and then laugh again when a giant sends you flying into the stratosphere. 🚀😂

So grab your sword, charge up your magic, and embark on the adventure of a lifetime! 🗡️✨ Just make sure to stock up on cheese wheels for those dragon encounters... 🧀🐉🏔️

You do the same thing, you wander around the same places, you fight the same bandit whether he's level 12 or level 48. The artificial intelligence is a joke, enemies get stuck on walls, enemies can be cheesed and kited in almost every situation that involves a dungeon or a cave. The single-player original experience is so disgustingly short that you basically HAD to buy the DLC content just to get more life out your purchase. The mod content that is free, is amazing, but the mod content that they have tried to convince people to buy (and they have) is hilarious. Virtually everything in Skyrim has been done better in every other RPG, even as far back as Morrowind. This is going to be a very unpopular opinion but.... here goes. I hated this game. Truly. Here's why. 

1: The main game story is short and boring AF. Sorry but it is. Can be conquered in 10 hours or so. Here is the story in 2 sentences. 
[spoiler] A guy has the power to speak dragon and learn their abilities. He has to kill an evil one who wants to destroy the world, The end. [/spoiler]

2: The graphics SUCKED, especially for the time it came out. 

3: The movement and combat are horse manure and oh so clunky. There were MANY other games out there at this same time, in the same vein that had nice, smooth and fun movement mechanics. This feels like something I would have played back in.... Oh WAIT!!! I did. Back when Marrowind released. *smh*

4: Dragons are massively bugged to this very day and often fly backwards and get stuck in the ground.

5: Used the same game engine from 15 years before its time

6: Touted as having 200+ endings. Lies. Changing one MINOR detail does not constitute an "Alternate Ending". Like re-branding a pack of skittles as a new flavor blend just because you took out all the yellow ones. 

7: Still wasn't even close to as good as Marrowind.

8: Final boss fight feels in no way epic or unique. Just fighting the same dragon you have been fighting but bigger and cooler looking but an easy kill even without crafting OP gear.

Upsides

Side quests are mostly cool. Lots of treasure to find. Crafting can make you OP beyond words. 

PS: I did not leave this review to help someone choose to buy this game because I dont know why you would, I did it more to piss off all the fanboys who somehow made this turd one of the most popular games ever. Like the year Madden won game of the Year. Morons.  

I can hear all the fanboys now exploding in their chairs and pants when they see my thoughts on this. Hope you wore your brown pants today gents.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Gameplay

The Skyrim is an RPG i.e., a Role Playing Game, Kindly don’t misinterpret it as Rocket Propelled Grenade (: -\), However the Energy you can put into it for leveling and improving character states is nearby. Having gone through the very humble 90 levels of improvement, I can say it require some serious amount of focus and retries, which is a fa.c.tor that takes some toll. The game consists of leveling system for enemies, items, characters and weapons. the main character\player level is gained through completing various main and side quests, this level progress makes the levels of enemies and items adjusted so that the gameplay can remain enjoyable. Weapons states becomes higher with leveling as well. The Game allows you to try so many varieties of weapons that a normal human, who may be a gamer, with would not even aware of existence of such vocabulary of weapons. This was my thought when I first played Oblivion and the Skyrim made it more memorable. The spell casting, is what makes the combat magical, given that I human, not aware of fighting mechanics other than shooting bullets, guns and vehicles. This is immersive as hell. Game allows you to choose your class by fighting style you want to play. If a human prefers more worldly combat, it can choose swords, shield and glorious medivals items... for other worldly combat it can choose spell casting for damage from distance as well as magical restoring the lost self damage by their huge Magika (Fast brain stat). skill trees like Restoration, Destruction, Illusion, Alteration, Conjuration etc. require the use of Magika. Small amount of This also helps with Strength, Agility and Armor. Avoiding most of the combat is also possible by sneaking, going invisible etc. The First person sword play is fantastic and engaging, player can use Swords, Bows, Axes and Hammers. Finishing moves are different for various weapon class, resulting in instant takeout. Bows and Arrows in combination of medival world puts you ages behind the current technology. The Skyrim open world is great to explore and most of the exploration require time taking yet enjoyable walking and horse riding etc., after that fast travel option becomes available. Caves are full of trapes and leveled creatures and contains good variety of in game items and weapons from fallen enemies.    

Graphics

The huge open World of Skyrim is full of colorful vegetation. Trees, pathways, flowing rivers, snow mountain range are realistic. smoke effects in caves as well as climate changing effect of outdoors gives sense of realism. The tree leaves animate with wind effect. The day night cycle is present with gradual change in outdoor lighting. Flames, sparks, magical effect all are great in visual appeal and pleasant to watch in combination with indoor lighting. Every unique variety of creatures, characters, items and weapons is in good looking details.

Characters and Animation

The characters are high in geometric detail and animation is not quite as jerky. First person view provides good details on models of weapon. Creature and other player classes have unique character models. The Huge Dragons in Skyrim world looks very detailed and player can admire the detail when it comes to the close combat.

Sound

The atmospheric sound is immersive and player can get lost in huge open world. Dialogs are not very repetitive and adds to realism. caves, rivers and other indoor areas are alive with sounds of flowing water, fire and other creatures usual natural indoor-outdoor sound. ice storms are also loud and atmospheric.

Story

The main quest is long and takes good amount of time to complete. It is quite rewarding regarding in game items. side quest some time also provides unique in game items, weapons etc.  

Conclusion

The experience is worth the playing of game, while admiring the beauty of medival world representation... but The Game is very time consuming given the RPG mechanics. 

Overall, 9/10

Dude, it's Skyrim. Just buy it.

Skyrim is a masterpiece of an open-world role-playing game that offers players a rich and immersive world to explore, filled with endless adventures, quests, and characters to discover. Developed by Bethesda Game Studios, Skyrim takes place in the province of Skyrim, a land of frozen tundras, towering mountains, and ancient ruins, where players take on the role of the Dragonborn, a hero with the power to slay dragons and save the realm from destruction.

One of the game's standout features is its open-ended gameplay, which allows players to approach the game however they see fit. Players can choose to focus on the main questline, or they can explore the world at their leisure, engaging in side quests, interacting with NPCs, and discovering hidden treasures and secrets.

The game's combat system is highly refined, with a range of weapons, spells, and abilities that players can use to take on enemies, including the game's iconic dragons. The game's leveling system is also unique, with players able to customize their character's skills and attributes to suit their playstyle.

Visually, the game is breathtaking, with a world that is both beautiful and dangerous. The game's sound design is also exceptional, with a dynamic soundtrack that adds to the game's atmosphere and sense of adventure.

Skyrim's modding community is also one of its greatest strengths, allowing players to further customize their experience with a range of user-generated content, from new weapons and armor to entire new storylines and quests.

Overall, Skyrim is a masterpiece of an RPG that offers players a world that is both immersive and believable, and countless hours of gameplay. Whether you're a fan of the genre or new to the world of RPGs, Skyrim is a game that is definitely worth playing.

"A Timeless Classic RPG that Never Gets Old"

Skyrim is a masterpiece of role-playing games that has captivated players for years. The game is set in a vast open-world filled with countless adventures, treasures, and dangers. Skyrim is a game that you can spend hundreds of hours exploring and still find something new every time you play.

The game's graphics and soundtrack are stunning and immersive, with epic scores that accompany the player's journey through the wilderness, snow-capped mountains, and ancient ruins. The sound effects are equally impressive, and they add a sense of realism and intensity to the game's combat and exploration.

Skyrim's gameplay mechanics are robust and diverse, allowing players to choose from a wide range of playstyles, including archery, magic, and melee combat. Players can also engage in crafting, smithing, and enchanting to enhance their weapons, armor, and potions.

The game's questlines are intricate and engaging, with many branching paths and choices that have significant consequences on the story's outcome. The game's factions and characters are memorable, with unique personalities and motivations that make them feel alive.

Skyrim's modding community is one of the most active and creative in the gaming world. With thousands of mods available, players can customize their game experience to their liking, adding new quests, weapons, and even entire new worlds.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The game's AI can be frustrating at times, with characters getting stuck or behaving erratically. The game's combat mechanics can also feel repetitive after a while, and some players may find the leveling system confusing or overly complex.

Despite its flaws, Skyrim is an unforgettable gaming experience that should be on every RPG fan's must-play list. Its stunning graphics, immersive soundtrack, engaging gameplay, and endless replayability make it a timeless classic that never gets old.

Title: A Timeless Adventure in a Breathtaking World!


Review:
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is an open-world action RPG that transports you to the vast and beautiful realm of Tamriel. With its rich lore, engaging storylines, and near-limitless exploration, Skyrim offers an unforgettable gaming experience that stands the test of time.

Gameplay: 10/10
Skyrim's gameplay features a perfect blend of exploration, combat, and character progression. The game's massive world is filled with diverse landscapes, hidden treasures, and countless quests, ensuring that there's always something new to discover. The skill-based leveling system allows you to create a unique character tailored to your preferred playstyle, while the game's dynamic combat keeps you on your toes. The freedom to explore, craft, and interact with the inhabitants of Skyrim makes for an immersive and captivating experience.

Graphics: 9/10
Even after all these years, Skyrim's visuals remain impressive, with stunning landscapes, detailed character models, and atmospheric weather effects. The game's art direction effectively conveys the rich history and culture of the world, making exploration a feast for the eyes. The modding community has also created countless graphical enhancements that can breathe new life into the game's visuals.

Sound: 10/10
Skyrim's sound design is exceptional, with a haunting and memorable soundtrack by Jeremy Soule that perfectly captures the game's atmosphere. The ambient sounds and effects are immersive, adding to the overall experience. The game also features a vast array of talented voice actors, bringing the characters and world to life.

Performance: 8/10
Skyrim's performance can be hit-or-miss, with some players experiencing crashes and bugs. However, the game's community has developed numerous unofficial patches and fixes that help to address these issues. Additionally, the game runs smoothly on a wide range of hardware, ensuring that it's accessible to players with various system configurations.

Replayability: 10/10
Skyrim offers near-infinite replayability, with hundreds of hours of quests, exploration, and character development. The game's radiant quest system ensures that you'll never run out of things to do, while the vast array of mods available can completely transform the experience, adding new content, gameplay mechanics, and visual enhancements.

Overall: 9.5/10
The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim is a masterpiece of open-world action RPGs, offering a vast, immersive world filled with rich lore, engaging quests, and endless exploration. Its captivating gameplay, stunning visuals, and memorable soundtrack make it a must-play for fans of the genre. Despite its occasional performance issues, the game's replayability and modding potential ensure that Skyrim remains a timeless classic that continues to enchant players to this day.

[h1] A legendary game... [/h1]

[b]What It Is:[/b]
A very Bethesda RPG experience with some deep series lore and what was, at the time, a pretty expansive ability to accept modded content, moreso than Oblivion.

[b]Gameplay:[/b]
Set foot into Tamriel once again, the legendary province of Skyrim. Birthplace of the nords, slayers of dragons, and some idiot trying to jump up a mountain so he can force shout a goat off of it. Yeah it's a bit ludicrous as far as RPGs go but it's fun!

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
Not hard, it's a very dumbed down RPG experience. That's not to say it isn't fun, but you aren't going to be breaking out the spreadsheets for this one folks.

[b]Graphics:[/b]
This older version of the game does need a lot for the graphics and the optimization of those graphics. It runs a lot less smoothly, but I don't know if that makes it any less stable.

[b]Audio:[/b]
The voice acting is pretty lackluster, but the soundtrack, dragons, shouts, and other general effects are really great. I would say using Sounds of Skyrim pushes this even further into perfection territory.

[b]Replay Value:[/b]
Insanely high with the myriad of mods and alternate stories you now have access to through the Nexus. I'm going to mention Nexus a lot. Because while this game does hold up on its own it is so much more with mods.

[b]What I Like:[/b]
Skyrim continues to permeate internet culture, and there's good reason why. While many berate the game for its numerous bugs and general lack of depth when compared to its sister titles, Skyrim is a fun experience for gamers of all types in its vanilla form. If you're a hardcore gamer, enjoy the delights of breaking the skill system to become a walking god. If you're a softy, just sit back and take in the countryside and cave systems of the Nordic lands.

The game really shines with its huge selection of mods from Nexus and other sources, many of which improve upon the aforementioned bugs and serve to deepen the experience Skyrim can give you. Make Skyrim a survival game if you want, or make it have guns, or even make yourself a chicken. Lots of things are possible with the mods, including enhanced ENB graphics.

[b]What I Don't[/b]
There are far too many rereleases of this game, causing fracture in the modding community. Aside from that, there are (as stated) numerous bugs and issues within the game which really need to be fixed via community patches to get the full pleasure from the game.
