[h1] Skyrim: The Game That Never Dies [/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]

Great game with deep lore and endless content.
Mods make the game infinitely replayable.
One of the most immersive RPGs ever made.
[b]Cons:[/b]

Oh wait, there are none. It's Skyrim.
[b]Final Verdict:[/b]

Skyrim is the gift that keeps on giving. With countless re-releases and remasters, Bethesda has proven that they will milk this game until the end of time. But hey, who needs new games when you can just keep playing Skyrim, am I right?

Sure, the graphics may be outdated and the combat clunky, but who cares? You can spend hundreds of hours exploring the vast open world, slaying dragons, and shouting at everything that moves. And if you get bored of the vanilla game, just add some mods! Want to turn dragons into Thomas the Tank Engine? Done. Want to replace every NPC with Macho Man Randy Savage? No problem.

And let's not forget about the constant stream of re-releases. Want to play Skyrim on your toaster? There's a version for that. Want to play Skyrim in VR? There's a version for that too. It's like Bethesda is daring you to keep buying the same game over and over again.

But let's be real here, we all know the real reason we keep coming back to Skyrim. It's because we can't resist the urge to steal every sweetroll in sight and fus-ro-dah unsuspecting NPCs off of mountains. So, if you're looking for a game that you can play for the rest of your life, look no further than Skyrim.

Skyrim is an open-world action role-playing game developed by Bethesda Game Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. Set in the world of Tamriel, players assume the role of the Dragonborn, a hero with the power to slay dragons and absorb their powers.

One of the standout features of Skyrim is its vast and immersive world, filled with interesting characters, epic quests, and hidden treasures. Players can explore the world at their own pace, taking on quests, battling dragons, and discovering ancient ruins and caves.

The game's story is well-crafted and engaging, with a strong emphasis on player choice and consequences. Players can make decisions that impact the game's world and story, with multiple possible endings based on their actions.

The game's combat system is satisfying and enjoyable, with a range of weapons and spells to choose from. The game also introduces a leveling system that rewards players for using specific skills, allowing them to become more powerful as they progress through the game.

The game's graphics are stunning, with beautiful landscapes, detailed character models, and impressive special effects. The game's sound design and music are also top-notch, with an excellent soundtrack and memorable characters.

Skyrim also features a vibrant modding community, allowing players to customize the game with a range of user-created content. This adds even more depth and replayability to the game, with endless possibilities for new quests, characters, and features.

Overall, Skyrim is a masterpiece of open-world RPG gaming, offering a vast and immersive world full of epic quests, memorable characters, and thrilling combat. Its engaging story, impressive graphics, and deep gameplay make it a must-play for fans of the genre and anyone looking for an unforgettable gaming experience.

Pros:
The combat is fun.

Almost all of the story is discovered through the main quest, unless you read books left lying around.

The character progression has a large variety to try out (replayable multiple ways).

There are lots of side quests.

The world is a good size.

Cons:
The graphics engine was not new and has been used in games prior to its release.  Although, there have been a few updates to the engine during its production.  The engine was dated prior to its release.

The engine, over a decade after its release, is dated.  You cannot play this game over 60hz or you will experience an unplayable game.

The graphics are dated.

The game crashes.  You must save very often.

The physics system is buggy.

NPC's have pathing issues, spawn in the air, spawn lying down and spin upwards to stand, etc.

The UI is a mess and inconsistent.  As an example, some dialogs on the PC will use Y/N for yes no questions and others will use Enter/Tab.  It's obvious that the UI was a port from a console and that this game was not re-designed well for the PC.

The dungeon design is inconsistent.  In some dungeons, the loot is horrible and others a magnitude of 20x the loot for the same combat situations.  It's obvious multiple designers kitted out dungeons and didn't follow a standardized loot model.
amazing

Strap in, because I'm about to tear Skyrim a new one.

Let's start with the graphics. Sure, they might have been impressive in 2011, but now they look like dog shit. The textures are muddy, the character models are ugly as sin, and the environments are bland and uninspired. And don't even get me started on the animations. They're clunky, stiff, and downright laughable. I've seen more realistic movements in a marionette show.

But it's not just the graphics that suck. The gameplay is a mess. The combat is sluggish and unresponsive, and the AI is dumber than a sack of hammers. Enemies just stand there and let you hit them, and the only challenge comes from the game's broken difficulty scaling. And don't even think about playing as a mage. The spells are weak, the animations are embarrassing, and the entire magic system is a joke.

And what about the story? It's a clichéd mess that's been done a million times before. You're the "chosen one" who has to save the world from some vague threat. Whoop-de-freaking-do. The characters are forgettable, the dialogue is wooden, and the voice acting is abysmal. It's like the developers got a bunch of interns to record the lines in a broom closet.

And let's not forget about the bugs. Holy shit, the bugs. Glitches, freezes, crashes, you name it. It's like the developers didn't even bother to test the game before they released it. And when they did release it, they didn't bother fixing any of the issues. They just left it to the modding community to clean up their mess.

And what's with the UI? It's like the designers were trying to create the most confusing and cumbersome interface possible. Navigating through menus is a chore, and trying to manage your inventory is a nightmare. It's like they were actively trying to make the game less fun to play.

Overall, Skyrim is a bloated, buggy, broken mess of a game that's only popular because of its modding community. If you want a good RPG, play something else. Anything else. Because this game is a steaming pile of dragon crap.

I've put a couple hundred hours into Skyrim on other systems. Even with that experience, I can't describe it as anything more than a bland time waster. It's miraculous; Bethesda somehow developed an RPG that hates any form of roleplaying beyond the most superficial layer. Every part of this game presents the bare minimum to pass as acceptable. I'll break them down as follows:

1) Combat is entirely button mashing and waiting on cooldowns with little strategy. Sit in front of enemies, slap them a couple times, wait for your stamina to regenerate, rinse and repeat. If you're playing a melee character, the default playstyle in just about any RPG, this is the entire game without exaggeration. Playing a mage build? Cry. Early game magic sucks ass, and even with a leveled up character you still end up mashing a single button so you can wait on a cooldown. The game's only meaningful difficulty comes from enemies with inflated health pools that behave exactly the same as the trash mobs you've been fighting with 10% of your brain capacity. At least playing a stealth archer is decently fun, which is good because it's the single viable build that nearly every player will end up gravitating to like a black hole

2) The huge map is largely empty, populated with copy-pasted fortresses and mind-numbing cave systems. The frost-coated landscapes of Skyrim are pretty at a glance, but quickly blur together into a grey mush as you realize nearly every area in the game is the exact same. Navigation doesn't consist of exploring for secrets or engaging with the world's layout; simply bring up your fantasy GPS and boot up Tamriel Maps so you can walk in a straight line for ten minutes. The same could be said for some of Bethesda's other titles, but Skyrim certainly puts the least effort into hiding how barebones its auto-generated map really is. The only decent areas in the game are the couple of curated towns like Whiterun and Solitude, but those locations are rarely populated with interesting things to do.

3) Quests are extremely simple, rarely presenting meaningful choices beyond "hehe, wouldn't it be so random and evil if you just killed this guy and failed his associated quests?" The surrounding narrative sucks too. I feel no need to elaborate on this point, considering that barely anybody finishes the game's main questline. Some of the lore is kinda neat, but instead of complementing the actual game you interact with, they're regulated to random books you can read. Don't get me wrong, I love some good environmental storytelling; I'm a huge fan of the Souls games. However, the lore in Skyrim doesn't overlap with the actual player experience. Instead, it truly just feels like booting up an in-game pdf and reading some fanfiction about the in-universe cosmology.

I can believe that many people, including Bethesda themselves, have a strong fondness for Skyrim. It's a decent gateway into more interesting roleplaying experiences that came before and after, including GOAT titles such as Fallout: New Vegas and Elden Ring. However, anybody still holding it up as a great game is huffing some major copium. For nearly every disease plaguing modern AAA game design, you can trace their infection back to Skyrim, patient zero.

Skyrim is a timeless classic and one of the greatest open-world RPGs of all time. The game's vast and detailed world, filled with breathtaking vistas, interesting characters, and diverse environments, is simply unmatched. The player has the freedom to explore, quest, and play in any way they desire, making every playthrough unique.

The combat system, while simple, is satisfying and offers a good challenge, especially when facing the various mythical creatures that roam the land. The magic system is well-designed, offering a wide range of spells to master and use in combat. The character customization options are also impressive, allowing players to tailor their playstyle to their preferences.

One of the standout features of Skyrim is its engaging story, filled with political intrigue, dragons, and ancient legends. The main questline is well-written and captivating, and the numerous side quests offer hours of additional gameplay.

Overall, Skyrim is a must-play for any fan of RPGs and open-world games. Its rich world, engaging story, and limitless possibilities make it a game that will continue to be enjoyed for years to come.

It's Skyrim. It's been around forever. My play time in this game across multiple titles, versions, etc., is not reflected in this number. I've been playing it since just after it came out and my cousin loaned it to me for my birthday.

If you REALLY want to know something about the game, just know that it's a wildly entertaining power fantasy with some questionable mechanics. Something in the game WILL break while you're playing. 50/50 if it's hilarious or entirely locks you out of progressing without reloading a previous save.

Beyond that, standard fantasy RPG tropes abound. Magic isn't really that good beyond mid-game. The most powerful damage spells are really only good as son as you unlock them. Level beyond that and their usefulness drops with each level. That said, the other schools of magic can provide you alternatives to leveling other skills - Illusion lets you go invisible at higher levels, bypassing the need to level sneak for instance - and magic in this game is fun, but not nearly what it was in previous installments.

stealth mechanics are decent. The indicator for how visible you are is fairly intuitive in the form of an eye that opens more and more until you're spotted and stealth is broken. Level up the skill and you can take advantage of damage multipliers for attacking while hidden. There's a meme in the community about "stealth archers" for a good reason; it's arguably the easiest way to play the game. Nobody will see you, you will do insane damge, and every combat encounter is over before the enemy even knows what happened. 

Physical combat is straightforward. Pick your preferred weapon, preferred armor class, and go hit things until they fall down. Blocking is a thing and can and will serve you when you're getting swarmed, but those instances are rare and most enemies can simply be battered down without much effort on your part. Kill move animations keep it entertaining, though they get kinda samey after a while. 

Visually the game is still gorgeous in its natural state. Character models are definitely dated, even with the updated graphics of anniversary or whatever, but the environments are just beautiful. Sound design is excellent, the voice acting is... Good. I've defintely heard worse, but the "Nord" accent is just weird. 

Honestly, if you like open world games, like fantasy RPGs, or are looking for something with a huge amount of ridiculous and slightly insane lore (look up "Dragon Breaks" and tell me that's not nucking futs) then you have absolutely nothing to lose by giving this game a try. Worst case you appreciate a few memes a bit better because a guard tells you about when he used to be an adventurer or asks you why you're upset. Best case scenario, a thousand hours go by and you can speak a few words of Dragon and have a character that can one-shot gods while laughing off ten times as much damage as you can dish out, and that's BEFORE you start modding the game and opening up THAT can of worms. 

Seriously, play the game without any mods all the way through the main story plus whichever side-quests you want to check out vanilla first. No mods, on Creation Club, just the base game/DLCs. THEN start adding in player-created content, because HOO BOY does it change everything.

The top notch open world RPG.

Skyrim, Todd Howards slam dunk on the gaming industry. The most re-released game of all time, for real Skyrim has been remade more times than the bible at this point but has had arguably more impact on our modern world and landscape. 
When this game dropped on 11-11-11 that was the beginning of the end, of Bethesda lol. It's basically the unholy accumulation of all the normies favorite mechanics from earlier games and with the visual flair to boot. It taught the company that they can get away with the bare necessities for what made their games so popular and good and thats why Fallout 4 came out the way it did.....................
Skyrim is probably my most played elder-scrolls game despite not being my favorite, I don't find it as mechanically interesting as Morrowind nor half as charming and well written as oblivion. Despite this though I have grown to appreciate the simplicity that Skyrim has to offer, it makes Skyrims more impressive dialogue and quests impact you just a little bit more.
However this effect is only achieved because most of Skyrim feels flat and stagnant so when you finally do stumble upon an actually interesting quest or storyline you can't believe what you're seeing cause you really don't expect there to be anything that substantial.
There is allot of fun to be had in the open world, but aside from that there isn't really much else here. The magic system from previous games has been stripped replaced instead by premade spells with pre-determined effects. There is basically no interesting spells in vanilla. There are a very minuscule amount of weapons and armors for you to pick from in the vanilla game. The vanilla game just feels empty as fuck.
Thankfully Skyrim mods still get made to this day lol

Steam, much like the red it, excels most in the practice of bowing to the oppression of the end consumer. This version is in all ways superior to the Special edition if you want to take ownership of your purchase. And it is hidden from the store proper. The expansions are marked up like a daddy-forsaken pole pilot with a fondness for V Twin-straddling adipose hairballs excreted into chaps, with three fewer front teeth than a meff maven. Also hidden from search in the Steam store, sharing in that outcome the due shame for the former, whilst punishing the latter worse than present society would abide. There is no option to buy the complete 32 bit Skyrim on Steam, even hidden.

Because Todd & Co doesn't like you.

They don't relish your access to the pinnacle of their creation, they resent modders doing the job better than the rented mule IP custodians were allowed to. You will own Arbitrary Coins (after you buy them for a rate competing with decent whiskey), Buy Skins, and Be Happy.

IF you merely choose to throw away your labor and resources whilst celebrating the elevation of your oppressor, proclaiming all the while how privileged you feel, the Special Edition beckons to you. It runs fine, and looks better than vanilla Skyrim. Which is good indeed, since any mods that get you chuffed will be immolated when the next patch comes through whilst you sleep or earn wages enough to buy Todd another disposable bidet, allowing you the auspicious privilege of broken saves, diminished QOL, a Kulak-worthy inventory stripping, and the instant absence of all the loot you stashed in that player-made bolt hole the next time you make your escape into your previously welcoming safe space.

"What do you want?!" I want Legendary Edition to remain an option. Todd need not even give it any more attention. Modders made it more stable than Todd ever did, made it look better, and balanced it to supremacy. He could be collecting $50 for the complete 32 bit experience, and I would buy it for every additional PC I installed it on, since mods really make the expense something beyond compare. But Todd chose to charge money for mods, basically. And they don't work very well. When you buy ice cream from a given vendor and you run a 37% risk of dysentery, you don't buy the ice cream. Well, Todd? Well, Steam? Yarr matey. Full sail, broadside canons load heavy shot, And ready chain shot on the bow tubes. Full ahead flank out into the Open Seas! We plot a chart for booty, and you can kiss ours, and our money goodbye!

There's full support (not just UI, but voice-over, books, everything) for several languages, which turns Skyrim into a really promising resource to get some solid language exposure. It is very cool to walk around places you know, talking with people you recognize, and in general just immerse yourself in your target language while understanding far more than you would if the material was entirely new (assuming you've played Skyrim before, that is). I haven't tried French yet, but the Japanese translation is really interesting - after a short adjustment period, the default guard quips and bandit verbal harassment has become almost as wonderfully normal and hackneyed as the English ones.

There's a problem with Skyrim versions and SKSE that requires some work, though. If you want to play with mods & with Japanese VO etc, you have to:
1) Install Skyrim in English (steam settings, not in-game - this will reinstall all the localized files)
2) Copy Steam\steamapps\common\Skyrim\TESV.exe to a safe place.
3) Install Skyrim in Japanese.
4) Replace the outdated japanese TESV.exe with the one you copied earlier.
5) Install SKSE, mods, etc as usual.

Good luck reading the handwritten font that books are written in if you're playing in Japanese though. I've read several books in the language, both modern novels and chunky old tomes, but deciphering these books is beyond me about 50% of the time. Maybe I just need to practice reading Sakamata's handwriting more.

Skyrim was my first foray into the Elder Scrolls series, and it immediately made me a fan. I love the fantasy setting, I love the huge amount of skill trees and perks to build around, I love all the different gear and magic available to use- it's really just an incredible RPG that can play differently every time you boot it up. 

The score of this game is fantastic; every time I pick it up and hear the Dragonborn theme on the main menu, I'm drawn in all over again. This sentiment extends to the dynamic music changes as different events play out in the overworld too, ranging from a random bandit whose ire I've drawn to a feisty dragon zooming in to get clapped. I really enjoy the fact that I can basically hear what's happening before I'm able to visually take it in.

The combat, while one of the lower points of the game, is still far from poor. There's not a lot of depth to the melee combat; you're typically just trading beat-sticks and stepping back or blocking to mitigate damage, whereas the enemy will just walk towards you in a straight line. That said, I do think there's plenty of room to spice it up for yourself with the inclusion of off-handing a spell, managing your shouts and powers in combat, or using bows/crossbows as a support for a companion. I could make the argument that this generic style of combat was necessary in order to include all of these different gameplay styles, but Dark Souls has just as many options and combat is its shining feature.

The amount of content is staggering as well. I truly think I could do multiple separate playthroughs that take dozens of hours apiece and not repeat a quest, (other than the intro and probably the quests to unlock Unrelenting Force because that's the most OP shit in the game and I love it). There's plenty of factions that have their own questlines, there's a civil war you can choose to get involved in, there's the destiny of the Dragonborn to uncover, cities to champion- there's just no end to what you can do in the land of Skyrim, and I think it's great that all of these are options.

Obviously Skyrim is a good game; it's been released like five separate times over three console generations in the last ten years. It also goes on sale all the time- you could pick up the base game + DLC for super cheap and already have a couple hundred hours of content to go through if you wanted to peruse it all, or you could dive into the modding scene and add a ton of stuff to the game: weapons, quests, armors, better graphics and textures, all of that. There's also weird sex stuff if you're a degenerate, but no judgement. Actually strike that, if you're gonna download that stuff, big judgement, go outside instead.

Cinematic playthrough here: https://youtu.be/UCYf3dUyvDI
Still a great game, modded or not.
Todd Howards the Skyrim

A revolutionary western RPG in its time, but only a decade later, it just doesn't hold up. At least not without a bunch of mods.

Even at release it was obvious that the mechanics of Skyrim were mostly unchanged from earlier entries in the series, going as far back as Daggerfall in 1994. The paint job was good enough to make up for it, but it was all just uninspired and kind of bland. It has the feeling of a game designed by engineers, not artists.

Today we're spoiled. And it's haaaaard to play an RPG with a main quest this bad, almost no variety in dungeons or environments, awful writing, repetitive voice acting, stiff animations, plastic facial expressions, etc. Virtually every RPG that has come out since puts it to shame.

I appreciate The Elder Scrolls as a series, and especially the early games, for being some of the first big fat fantasy worlds gamers got to explore. But Skyrim kind of sucks, and it's the last one I would go back and play today.

The wonderful mess that is Skyrim is highly recommended for people who just want to have fun in a fantasy world without necessarily having to deal with pesky world-saving quests, tough moral choices, or any sort of complexity. The game has all these, it's just that you can go 400 hours in without ever having to deal with them.

Do expect:
- Falling mammoths and little girls, FTL-travelling cows, and other oddities.
- Extremely polite wildlife, that will only hunt YOU, but rarely each other.
- Paper thin NPC characters, who sound the same when talking about their daughter's gruesome death as when talking about their breakfast.
- A truly staggering amount of never to be patched bugs, glitches, and the like, that has become a stuff of legends.
- So much fun on your adventures, that you will stop caring about all of the above.
- The Community saving the day with enough mods to make you forget about your human existence and real life goals.

This version doesn't have all the bells and whistles of SkyrimSE but still is worth gold especially if you can find all the hidden DLC's on Steam. 

Hearthfire is the one to get, if you want to do things like buy houses, adopt children, or get married. That is a must have for any Skyrim Player.   

There is also a free Standalone Total Conversion Mod on steam called Enderal: Forgotten Stories so when you buy this game you can get two games for the price of one. Totally worth 19 dollars.. Unlike many other games on steam you will never want a refund.

ABOUT THIS GAME
EPIC FANTASY REBORN
The next chapter in the highly anticipated Elder Scrolls saga arrives from the makers of the 2006 and 2008 Games of the Year, Bethesda Game Studios. Skyrim reimagines and revolutionizes the open-world fantasy epic, bringing to life a complete virtual world open for you to explore any way you choose.

LIVE ANOTHER LIFE, IN ANOTHER WORLD
Play any type of character you can imagine, and do whatever you want; the legendary freedom of choice, storytelling, and adventure of The Elder Scrolls is realized like never before.

ALL NEW GRAPHICS AND GAMEPLAY ENGINE
Skyrim’s new game engine brings to life a complete virtual world with rolling clouds, rugged mountains, bustling cities, lush fields, and ancient dungeons.

YOU ARE WHAT YOU PLAY
Choose from hundreds of weapons, spells, and abilities. The new character system allows you to play any way you want and define yourself through your actions.

DRAGON RETURN
Battle ancient dragons like you’ve never seen. As Dragonborn, learn their secrets and harness their power for yourself.
MATURE CONTENT DESCRIPTION
The developers describe the content like this:

This Game may contain content not appropriate for all ages, or may not be appropriate for viewing at work: General Mature Content

SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS
MINIMUM:
OS: Windows 7/Vista/XP PC (32 or 64 bit)
Processor: Dual Core 2.0GHz or equivalent processor
Memory: 2GB System RAM
Hard Disk Space: 6GB free HDD Space
Video Card: Direct X 9.0c compliant video card with 512 MB of RAM
Sound: DirectX compatible sound card
RECOMMENDED:
Processor: Quad-core Intel or AMD CPU
Memory: 4GB System RAM
Video Card: DirectX 9.0c compatible NVIDIA or AMD ATI video card with 1GB of RAM (Nvidia GeForce GTX 260 or higher; ATI Radeon 4890 or higher)

I like reviewing games. I like trying to put something as abstract as an experience into specific words. But I often write too many positives, shying from negatives thinking if I play it more I'll get it. Just by instinct, in appearance, I personally shy away from open worlds and that therefore I shouldn't comment. Just an indie game worshipper. But, truthfully, I have a lot of problems with this game in the current amount I've played. So I will write a negative until further notice.

I really, really want to like this game. I really want to be able to sink my teeth into it. I love the idea of the world and the setting. I want to look weird humming on the Dragonborn theme obsessing over the world. Everyone seems to rave on about it, as among open worlds as among one of the better ones and if thats the case all I think is 'how?' How is this such a classic? What am I not fundamentally getting? Am I impatient? No... I am very patient when it comes to having something to do and focus on. Am I uncreative? Possibly... I'm not 100% used to RPGs or open world sandboxing per se, maybe I'm not 'setting my own role play' well enough. But honestly at the core, I feel like there should be something enticing in the first place to do that. And there just isn't.

What are my main gripes? Well, it takes way too bloody long for anything to happen and is very bland and homogenous in the core aspects. Maybe things pick up later down the line, maybe. But that's only inevitable, once you've explored everything and got the fast travel. The actual manner of getting to that point though? Just not fun.

First, the movement. You have to painstakingly trek from place to place. To progress any level of the story or even your abilities, you have to walk. And walk. And walk. You can't even sprint, you run out of stamina if you do that. You walk, spring, take a breather, and walk. So you just walk. Until you find what you need. Then you walk all the way back. You have to trek up a whole mountain for I don't even know how long just to learn one of your most fundamental basic abilities, the shout. There is a fast travel ability once you find it, but only if you've already gone to the place. If you are going to waste my time for 13 hours in this way before I've got even the slightest grasp of the world or a novel mechanic, why bother? It also gives a feeling of a not flowing story-if you are to have an open world, the idea is that the world is open, my experience is open. So when you paint down a linear 'core' path in the first place and say 'meet at blank to do blank, now meet at blank to do blank', it really kills the immersion.

Maybe I play the game wrong-maybe wanting to immerse myself in the story and go point to point is not the right way to play. I took tips-explore freely, as you are going down a path. Using the stroll from place to place as a moment of reflection on the scenery. The issue of taking way too long for stuff to happen for no real gain is still there though. You walk and see the vast wilderness. Cool, but it doesn't feel distinct enough to the other snowy mountain you saw. It feels all rather grey in style. But an even bigger problem is the wandering is contrary to your goal-it is just one big empty space separating you and from where you need to be.

I think utilizing wandering is an excellent idea in games-let me mention one game that does it brilliantly-The Witness. Not just because all the areas feel fresh and distinct but because the nature of the world means completion happens at every point in the map, always. So you are always finding something to do. In Skyrim, all your main progression is at specific points you need to get to. Sure there are quests and other things scattered and I'll get to that but basically, it means you don't get any satisfaction towards the game during the wandering period. Making an excuse that I just need to be patient and find my own way to pass the time is not going to cut it given the context of this game. Aren't I supposed to be fighting dragons or something?

Maybe you come across a village, find a dungeon, explore it. But it doesn't feel satisfying. Because it doesn't feel any newer really. There may be a few tidbits mentioned that maybe you could explorer 'more' lore to-but it has no real depth of impact to me and doesn't feel it ties into a larger whole. Sure, that's also basically real life but is that what I want from a game? No. Everyone you talk to sounds so bland and disinterested too. Which is annoying since that is how you are supposed to learn about the world you are in. I naturally want to hear everything they say but I just get annoyed half the time. I think I'd much rather get my tutorial from the infodump text sheet style of tutorial, seriously. Sometimes they give crucial information on how to get somewhere but I just miss it because zzzzzzz...

But even worse, the combat feels while in some sense 'solid' and I wanted to view it as a positive but it just, feels really really boring. Your attack options are... swing a sword! And swing a sword. Maybe block, wait then swing. I personally use a bow, since it is the most interesting. Crouch and aim, now I have some actual layer of skill. For a combat focused game, there is no satisfaction to the combat. Just who swings at the other the most wins. Maybe you use magic and just hold it down on them and they get status effects. Sure, maybe there is a better depth there. But nothing feels any different, especially not when starting out. Woooooow... I already feel so sluggish and that certainly doesn't help matters. 

I come across a dragon at some point while trekking. Cool, great to fight a dragon! The only issue is in my current state, it feels there is absolutely nothing I can do but walk my slow ass backwards because I have basically no good tools to fight with. So why place me in that situation in the first place? This doesn't feel like the interesting kind of 'undefeatable souls boss' to return to later after getting pummeled, it just feels like an annoying obstacle badly paced with the tools I've been given. I'd want to have those tools to fight properly, but that doesn't occur fast enough and probably requires yet more walking place to place.

One other thing I take note of though that cements all my points is that this isn't a good RPG which I've been told before. People play it to 'fuck around' and mod it and shit. Which is of course great, that is what open world games are good at. But the base game should also be fine with solid mechanics. When someone showed me the way you actually deal with shop in this game is by sticking a bucket on someone and stealing, it just felt like removing a core element

So, the combat is boring. The movement is sluggish. The world is homogenous. The immersion and pacing is completely killed for me. I've spent 13 hours and little has happened.

I feel perhaps people begin to expect monotonous nonsense as something to truck through in games. And don't mind sinking time into doing nothing. But not me. I like my game to be more consistently a great or interesting time throughout.

"The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim" is a fantastic open-world game that offers endless hours of adventure. From the sweeping landscapes to the immersive gameplay, there's so much to love about this game. But one aspect that really sets "Skyrim" apart is its focus on rim jobs. No, not that kind of rim job – we're talking about the kind of rim job that involves exploring the game's many dungeons and ruins. These dark, mysterious locations are full of danger and loot, and they provide the perfect setting for some intense rim job action. Whether you're sneaking through a bandit hideout or delving into the depths of a Dwemer ruin, there's always something exciting waiting around the next corner. So if you're a fan of rim jobs (the exploration kind, not the other kind) and open-world games, "The Elder Scrolls: Skyrim" is a must-play. Just be sure to watch out for those dragons – they can be a real pain in the rim.

This game is a true masterpiece. Every screenshot can be framed as a painting. Although the atmosphere is more sombre than the landscapes in Oblivion (the previous Elder Scrolls game), the open world provides hours of adventuring. The storyline can be followed in a linear fashion, but there's a lot of fun to try out the different faction quests, and to go different ways within the game play such as turning into a werewolf or a vampire (on top of your original race you started the game with). Even with weeks of game play you'll still find things to do in the game. Difficulty of the game is levelled and there is a natural progression in building your skills. If ever the developers bring out a game that contains cyrodyll, skyrim and the shivering isles in one game, It will be unsurpassed. Been waiting for the next elder scrolls since 2019 when the first whispers of its release were heard. Sadly I think that Skyrim is the last and the greatest of the elder scrolls games, because the majority of the team that created Skyrim have left the developing company.

It's a little late in the game to be writing a review for a very outdated version of the game but oh well. Let me start by saying I'm a modder and an intense one at that. I have recommended the original Skyrim edition because of its modding capabilities and how many mods are out there for it. The special edition simply does not have near as many. 

Now i will focus on the actual game without mods. Skyrim is a timeless game. The only games i can think of that have had a longer lifespan than Skyrim are Doom and Counter Strike, People will still be playing this game for at least another 5 years maybe 10. There's a good reason for this. The freedom to move about is very involving however the actual open world outside of cities can feel quite empty with a lack of enemies in the wild. This can be fixed by mods. The combat system was very intuitive for it's time but can now feel rather clunky and simple. This can be fixed with mods. The game can be VERY buggy but as they say " it's not a bug its a feature" There is so much to do in this game that I have dumped hundreds of hours into this and will stay dumping hundreds of hours more because like I said there is so much to do and even after 500 hours there is still much left to uncover. I have completed all of the DLC story lines multiple times both with mods and without.

I'm going to go into detail about specific mechanics of the game to expound about the core aspects of the game.

First off, the companion mechanic allows you to develop an authentic feeling relationship with your companions. I've never played a game where you can marry companions or other NPCs so that is something that separates this game from others.I will say that their AI can be really stupid sometimes. When you're trying to stealth attack specifically Lydia will go balls to the wall and just clobber on the nearest enemy as soon as she spots them ruining your stealth approach. Due to situations like this stealth is a useless and non-existent mechanic in this game.Another aspect is the ability to adopt children. No other game includes that that i've ever heard of.

Now let's focus on the combat. The combat system at the time it was created was ground breaking. People lost their minds over the ability to equip fire hands and a sword in the other. There are still few games that allow you to have a set up like this. Nowadays in comparison to other first person RPG combat games the combat system can feel clunky and very repetitive as you're just swinging your weapon chaotically and raising your shield to block. Most games in the modern day include a dodging mechanic which is either a sidestep or a rolling move. This is non-existent mechanic in the game however this can be fixed with mods.

Now on to the skill tree and upgrade system. The skill tree is not very intuitive as some skills feel out of place and they cannot be unlocked until later in the game and its feels like it should have been able to be unlocked much earlier in the game. The UI for it is very pretty however and very unique compared to other games whereas most modern games like this take Elden Ring for example have a very complex unlocking system and it takes time to learn. With Skyrim you can simply scroll through the constellations and see how the skills build up and plan accordingly of what you want to unlock and when.

Now on to the main story and DLC story content. The story is rather simple but the relationships you build with the characters involved in the stories feel very real and authentic. The characters speak in a natural tone and say things that if this were real life they would be things that somebody ( or something) would say. There arent many choices you get to make in the stories other than the major choice you make in the civil war. The correlation between stories can feel very strange because you can go all the way through a storyline beat the final boss of the main storyline then come back to a secondary story and people speak to you and treat as if you have not become something of a god and have saved the world so depending on the path you've taken it can feel very awkward. You have to abandon the sense of lack of correlation between the stories .

This is all that I will leave a review for as this is very long winded already. I could write for an hour on this game but I will elave you with this, Skyrim is an amazing game and set the precedent for how modern open world RPGs operate and every game since then has taken concepts from it and have developed it. I didn't get into this game until many years after it's inception so I don't like this game purely because of nostalgia but because this is a genuinely well made game. Of course there are problems and much mroe than modern open world games but that is because open world games were still in their infancy when this game came around. Bethesda is known for leaving bugs in and I think that is an endearing aspect of the game and why people will continue to play it because with every play-through something strange and new will happen whether it be because of strange bugs or simply because they put so much time into this game that there are always new things to discover. If you have read this review i appreciate you and if you've never played this game I highly recommend it!

There was a time when Skyrim's graphics were cutting edge, when Fus Ro Dah had not been memed across the nets, when the voice of the Dragonborn had not been heard. That time passed quickly into memory and then legend. This game is a cultural icon now. The graphics didn't age well, nor did the story, and the game was never balanced. In-spite of that, the Bethesda strategy of throwing people into a fantasy sandbox is a good one.

The role playing options in this game allowed you to be a hero, a thane, an architect, a mage, a spouse, a farmer, or a drunk fisherman down by the river, and pretty much anything else too. No matter what kind of RPG fan you are there is likely something in this game that could appeal to you, and likely for 100 hours or more. It's not the best game, but it's certainly a good one.

Skyrim has been praised for its expansive and detailed game world, its engaging and complex storyline, and its impressive graphics and sound design. The game's rich and diverse world is filled with memorable characters, locations, and quests, and its robust modding community has added even more content and features to the game.

However, some players and critics have criticized Skyrim for its repetitive gameplay and quests, and for its bugs and technical issues. The game's combat and character progression systems have also been criticized for being unbalanced and shallow.

Overall, Skyrim is a highly-rated and successful game that offers players a vast and immersive world to explore. Its repetitive gameplay and technical issues may not be to everyone's taste, but for those who are fans of open-world action-adventure games, it offers hours of entertainment and enjoyment.

If you're dumb enough to buy this game in 2022, it's still okay, but why?

Needless to say, this game is a legend at this point. At the time the graphics were pretty nice (though I do think they're heavily dated now). Where the game excels is character creation and choosing what kind of path to follow as you build the character. Combat is generally easy and still fun. The story is honestly pretty mild and nothing special, and given how these games work it's pretty much impossible to have any good character development.

I found it not to hold up as well on replay. If you complete the game the first time around, there's not much new to see playing it again. The quests are the same.

Those minor things aside, the game is a well-deserved 10/10, probably in my top 20 all-time list. Even if you only play it once you have probably at least 200 hours of high-quality play waiting for you.

I want to like this game because I don't wanna be that elitist douche who just hates on things just for being popular.

But this game is a steaming pile of garbage that people pretend is the greatest video game ever made. It's a mediocre RPG and an okay action game. WHEN IT WORKS. Nearly every single system is heavily flawed and cumbersome if not actively broken. This is a handbook for how not to make a game. The engine is bad. The scripting is bad. The ai is bad. The performance is bad. The world level map quest and combat design are all total crap. Some of the quests are alright but most of them suck, especially the main story. There are some individual elements that work out well, namely the art style. Watching this game be played by other people is the best and only way to squeeze any actual enjoyment out of this garbage. If you're a tiny brained easily amused simpleton chasing the trail of dopamine squirts on your way to a false sense of happiness, be my guest to waste your time on this bundle of operant conditioning stuffed into a pile of cheese wheels.

This game was fine in 2012 as a slightly improved Fallout 3 with dragons. Just like Oblivion was fine in 2008. But ultimately this is such a product of its time that there is no joy that can come out of this program that isn't viewed through the rose tinted goggles of nostalgia, or ironically enjoyed for the memes, or high off your mind on mushrooms. Todd Howard is a hack of a director and if this is your favorite game of all time you have all the taste as diehard Nickelback fans who claim they're the greatest band in the world. Because this game is just the Nickelback of RPGs. It's FINE, it's JUST OKAY, it's nothing special. And if you understand and accept that then you'll get exactly what you pay for.

Oblivion was a monumental landmark in open world game design. Fallout 3 was a monumental landmark in open world game design. Fallout New Vegas was and still is one of the greatest games of all time. Skyrim is a monumental landmark in pure visual aesthetic. But in gameplay it's just okay, AT BEST. But "just okay" is not enough to play something over a decade old. If Starfield and Redfall are just Skyrim in space or on a new engine, it's going to suck too. Bethesda are overrated and so is this game. Fus Ro Dah it off a cliff / 10.

Я довакин. Последний драконорожденный. Единственный, к кому Ярлы всех городов могут обратиться по вопросу угрожающего им дракона.

Я прирожденный убийца. Только попросите меня и Я пробьюсь через сотни бандитов, чтобы прикончить их главаря. Я убью самого императора за хорошее вознаграждение.

Я отличный вор. Вас интересует кольцо с бриллиантом, которое супруга ярла не снимает никогда? Я принесу его вам

Я идеальный наемник. Мне можно поручить что угодно. Я залезу в любую задницу мира ради древней скрижали.

Даже боги и Даэдра доверяют мне важные дела. Они знают, что Я выполню всё, что угодно, лишь бы этот проклятый значок задания перестал мылить мне глаза.

У меня есть только один недостаток. Если вы попросите меня сделать что-то, Я всё исполню, не сомневайтесь. Но вот когда это произойдет, не знает даже Хермеус Мора.

Я зачищаю очередное подземелье и нахожу искомую эльфийскую чашку. В двух шагах от подземелья находится форт, который меня кто-то и где-то просил зачистить. После зачистки Я вижу вдалеке медведя и вспоминаю, что одна девушка просила меня добыть 10 шкур этих животных. После охоты Я замечаю, что вещи складывать больше некуда и иду в близлежащий город, чтобы сплавить барахло. По дороге на меня нападают вампиры и на теле одного из них, Я нахожу записку, которая добавляет еще один, мурыжащий взгляд, значок задания на мою карту. Потом меня находит гонец, который говорит, что возрождается какая-то там королева волчица и во всём Скайриме только мне не лень пойти и прибить её. Уже вся карта усыпана этими проклятыми значками заданий. Десятки городов, сел, домов, фортов и везде Я кому-то что-то должен!!!

После недели таких мытарств, Я со словами "Да ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ вы со своими проблемами сами, уроды недоделанные" сваливаю в заброшенную, в тайге, хижину, ловить рыбу в ближайшем озере. Я живу там тихой мирной жизнью, пока меня не находит очередной гонец! (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! Как он меня нашел???) С сообщением, что в какой-то жопе мира открылся музей.

Всё это время эльфийская чашка, о которой вы мечтали с 3 лет, пылится у меня на дне рюкзака. Получите вы её лишь тогда, когда меня волею судьбы занесёт в ваш богом забытый городок (потому что имбецил, который мною управляет, не хочет пользоваться фаст тревелом). И не дай бог, вы словите глюк и не захотите забирать у меня эту чашку. Я вам её засуну туда, где драконы не летают и фалмеры не кукарекают.

The funny thing about Skyrim is that it's kind of bad: grimy textures, auto-generated filler quests, unbalanced mechanics, brain-dead combat, bad voice acting, wooden animations, buggy scripting...I could go on. And yet, it's not a bad game. It's one of the defining titles of the 7th console generation.

I can't really explain the appeal. Part of it is probably the endless hype and excitement from when it came out--12 years ago, I can still remember how bad I wanted to play this game--but it's not just nostalgia. There are plenty of other western RPGs with open worlds (bigger ones, even) that don't hit the same either.

There is one specific thing I enjoy about this game which I can point out, at least: how broken it is. It's kind of strange, but I think the game is much more engaging *because* it's a mess. Trying to get unstuck from weird level geometry, breaking out the console to fix glitched questlines, creating totally busted equipment...it's fun. The way I think of it is, after the enemies in the game are no longer a threat, you start playing against the software itself, trying to hack, cheese, and exploit your way through to the end.

I think Skyrim is required reading for anyone who plays games.

This is one of the best games in my steam library, and I have some pretty good games. Lets get the worst out of the way first. (There's not much) It can get a little repetitive when it comes to dungeon raiding, but that's only if you never change your play style. Some of the animations are a little sketchy, but that's only compared to today's games. Now that that's out of the way, lets get to the good stuff. This game is amazing. The world is HUGE and has so many places for you to explore. Its got all of the things you need to RP if that's your style. (inns, carriages, fancy clothes, random items, ect.) It is a full on RPG with a skill tree for everything you could think of. (pick-pocketing, lock-picking, archery, 2 handed, 1 handed, BEING A GOD**MN WEREWOLF, ect.) Its got so many quests that you probably wont ever find them all without using a guide. The playtime on this game is the longest on any game I have ever played excluding MMOs. It seems the only thing this game is missing is online multiplayer. If ALL OF THAT is not enough for you, there is also a HUGE selection of mods in the steam workshop for you to add to your game and make it EVEN MORE EXTENSIVE. There is everything from Lord of the Rings weapons to Flaming horses to THOMAS THE TRAIN DRAGONS in the workshop. WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR!? BUY THIS GAME! 10/10 would write a super long review again.

Further reading. It's really, really good - with one small caveat: vanilla Skyrim is one of the most dull, uninspired RPG experiences imaginable. They dumbed-down or removed completely systems from the previous titles that didn't need to be, and only made the game world/player experience richer. Playing 'nilla Skyrim is like watching paint dry.

However, as someone who's been modding/playing modded ES games since 2003, and a lifetime Premium member of Nexus since '05, I can assure you that taking the time to learn properly how to install mods to your Skyrim will give you the best RPG experience possible. The sheer amount of mods out there guarantee, that if you patiently search for what you like and test what works, you can custom tailor the ideal single-player fantasy RPG for yourself. And you may find yourself so enthralled with your adventures, the main quest takes a back seat to all the wonder you uncover at every turn. Bethesda created a wonderful framework for us to sculpt into something beautiful. It's just up to you to decide if the task is worth it.

I should add the main reason I haven't switch to SSE yet, despite wanting to do so, is that not all of my 500 some mods I play with are fully/officially ported yet. And I'm just far too fond of some of the characters I've created over the years.

Good, but with hindsight, the SE version is better since it has all the DLC's and the currently more active modding community. the creation club stuff ended up changing nothing and being entirely ignorable.

Without a doubt the greatest RPG ever made, except for maybe Witcher 3, but that is debatable.  After hundreds of hours on many different platforms I still find things I’ve never seen before on each play through, even though for some reason I alway go for the same stealth archer assassin type of character.  On my last run I did almost everything in the game, even murdered innocent people in each city, just for a simple achievement.

Graphics are still quite stunning even 10 years after release, the game is as immersive as many new releases and it runs well on older machines. It tends to be on sale many times throughout a year, so for those who've never played it (or never finished it), it's an easy recommendation.

Elder Scrolls: Skyrim is a game for everyone aged 15 and older. Whether your 15 or 95 the Bethesda developers have created the most immersive, explorative, and rich game of its "generation". 10/10 experience from the 200hrs I've put into game with multiple different characters. If I had to criticize; the only failing with the game is that it's too friendly to the gamer. Skyrim, unlike Morrowind, allows faster progression of story and quests that can be off-putting to those of us that struggled for weeks on hand yet succeeded in "Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind". Give yourself distance from irl and enter a world you have never known with "Skyrim".

Well, what can I say? It's Oblivion, but colder. The freedom of the Elder-Scrolls-games is legendary, and the main quest is captivating. Even though I miss the beautiful autumn landscapes and forests and the golden dusks from Oblivion, I love the cold snowy mountains of Skyrim all the same. It's incredible how you can almost feel the cold air in front of your computer thanks to little perks like the slight steam effect on the loading screens and the carefully and perfectly designed SFX. It's a game where you don't even have to do any quests - you can just enjoy the solitude of a high mountain or go on a long journey through the Northern taiga. I can warmly (heh) recommend mods like Frostfall and Campfire to truly turn this game into a hiking simulator. The atmospheric tracks by Jeremy Soule, "Wind Guide You", "Unbroken Road" and "Ancient Stones" standing out particularly, turn this game into an absolute masterpiece, and to date one of the best ones I've ever played.

Skyrim is one of the most important games to me, ever. I have such a connection with it and reminds me of the good old days.

It's Elder Scrolls, duh.

Skyrim is an amazing game and should be played by everyone that likes gigantic open-world role-playing in a magical-medieval setting with deep awe-inspiring lore, a long main story line, and seemingly unending side quests.

I believe the above provides the gist to why everyone should play Skyrim, but to add some more detail about actual gameplay here are some highlights:
- Inventory management,
- First and/or third person play you choose at any time,
- Fun combat,
- You will do battle against various types of dragons in the main quest line, but also through random encounter battles with dragons that spawn without warning throughout the world,
- Also, dragon fights are much more than just a wow factor you want to fight and defeat them for a real reason that is directly tied to a gameplay and is also baked into the lore of the world itself,
- Custom crafted armor and weapons, accessories, enchanting, spell configuration, alchemy, extensive skill trees for all play-styles, and dungeon diving,
- The base game is gigantic on it's own and then there are multiple DLCs that not only expand the map but also add depth to the game with unique items, spells, races, and powers. One such DLC also adds a more in depth base building mechanic that is awesome. You can own homes in the base game and make them yours, but this particular DLC adds so much more.
- Remastered graphics, you can play the game on a potato computer or crank it up to ULTRA-bliss on a powerful PC and in either case you will love playing Skyrim.
- Also, Skyrim has one of THE BEST character customization tools I have seen anywhere.

My personal recommendation is buy the remastered version with better graphics and purchase the "all DLCs included" bundle they are definitely worth it and the DLCs are togglable meaning that even if you own them you don't have to use them and can play the base game as much as you like. I absolutely love playing this game and after multiple character builds, base game and then game with DLCs, and literal real-world years of playing I still love starting a new save file and replaying the entire game from zero to this day (09/18/2022).

This game is my favourite of all games ever created. You can't even imagine how many hours I've spent in this game on Xbox 360. Yeah you should buy the Special Edition one, but I got this one A LONG LONG time ago.

If you looked at each of this game's systems individually, I think you'd find that they're all mediocre at best. Yet, somehow, moreso than any game I've ever played, the end product is truly so much more than the sum of its parts. 

The story isn't great. The RPG mechanics are watered down compared to it's predecessors. Yet the feeling of freedom this game provides players really is incomparable. With one of the largest, most active modding communities around, you can tailor this experience from top to bottom to fit your ideal fantasy adventure. 

I've played this game at least once a year since I got it, and I imagine I'll be doing so for many years to come.

Coming back to re-review the product that nobody has wanted or needed a review for in the past nine years.

This is an eminently [i]playable[/i] game, but miserably simplistic in order to not over-tax the minds of the lowest common denominator.  It's optimized as a cash grab (as a decade of re-releases has abundantly shown), sacrificing complex decision making mechanics for low-commitment multiple choice which insults the... less linear of mind.  This is high fantasy for CoD players.

The plot is bad.  That is not an opinion; it's objective fact.  It is utterly ignorant of fundamental plot structure, driven instead by a pandering to instant gratification.  It takes about one hour of play to be identified as the Messiah-du-jour—a plot point which would generally be reserved until late in the second act.  Where exactly do you go from here?  Well... you don't.  You jump directly to the top, with little exposition, character development or rising action.  I mean, shoot—you start out at your own execution, which is violently interrupted by the BBEG for no apparent reason.  Isn't that supposed to happen at the [i]end,[/i] and with some sort of justification beyond [i]"I'm too sexy for this plot"?[/i]  [spoiler]And then, in the final hypothetically climactic battle, you're not actually a heroic warrior so much as a pro-active meteorologist.  [i]Wah-wahhhhh.....[/i][/spoiler]

Let's talk about the dialogue.  It's awful.

Avenici (having just heard the magically-broadcast announcement of a newfound Dragonborn by an elite band of legendary monks, followed immediately by an account of the PC devouring a dragon's soul, and speaking directly in front of the Nord subject's autocrat brother who could have him executed for essentially no reason whatsoever):  [i]"Hrongar, calm yourself. What does any of this Nord nonsense have to do with our friend here? Capable as he may be, I don't see any signs of him being this, what, "Dragonborn.""[/i]

Hrongar (having had his race and system of beliefs pointlessly slurred by a bureaucrat of gross and—as it turns out—shockingly ubiquitous stupidity): [i]"Why, you puffed up ignorant!"[/i]

Nazeem (smugly superior, unsolicited, and EVERY FRIGGING TIME YOU GET WITHIN 10 FEET OF HIM):  [i]"Do you get to <the largely unavoidable public space just up these steps> very often?  Oh what am I saying, of course you don't."[/i]

One can only conclude that Bethesda left the writing up to a motley assortment of middle school students with limited life experience and questionable literary tastes.

A brief, very incomplete point-form list of further sins:
-'Classless' system which results in every character becoming a stealth archer
-Quality Bethesda user interface
-Bethesda QA and support
-Further deprecation of skill system, including key play elements (notably acrobatics)
-Complete deprecation of stat system
-Reduction of magic system to idiot simplicity/utility
-Nonsensical 'conveyor belt' dungeon design for convenient pseudo-exploration
-Idiot-friendly 'puzzles' (attempted aversion by suggesting that these are to keep undead [i]in,[/i] but if there's a convenient rear exit...)
-Inconsistent setting details (ie: Khajiit are not allowed into cities... unless they're player characters, in which case nobody seems to care)
-'Colour' NPCs are often obnoxious, and cannot be interacted with in any meaningful way.  Speaking of which...
-M'aiq the Apologist

What a sorry dog's breakfast of disappointment.  But... it [i]is[/i] playable, if you're willing to lower your expectations.  And thank god for the modding community, without which Skyrim frankly wouldn't be worth the time and money.  Consider this a 'thumbs sideways', and a promise to myself that I will not forget Bethesda's exponential decline in quality when TES6 finally drops.

Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

Besides the stupid-ass overused meme made off this game's intro, Skyrim is awesome. 

There is an incredible amount of work put into this game's story and writing, and satisfying combat. This combat can be combined with magic, spells, potions, and healing items. This game is practically pitch perfect. Infact, I feel that it is perfect. Of course the graphics could be better or less dull, but you can just buy the special edition. But the graphics are still impressive for such an old game, I admit. 

There are also many mods you can install, like changing the amount of blood, skipping the long intro, and some lewd mods for lonely men, who have never been touched by any woman.
Even in 2022 it still holds as one of the best RPGs available.

Kind of goes without saying, this was a revolutionary game. There are of course several takes on ancient Nordic culture in the art styles of games (a standout is God of War), but Skyrim's Norse art style preceded many other prominent styles and likely inspired them. The game has a great deal of fun quests with freedom of choice in mind. However, there are two large weaknesses:
-Using a lot of magic spells mid to late game is simply not viable.
-Settling the differences between the Empire and Stormcloaks to fight the dragon menace. That meeting not only takes way too long and tanks the pace of the campaign, it also has little to no effect on the player relations with the factions. If you're siding with the Stormcloaks and essentially decide against them with every concession, they don't seem to mind. Granted, it does actually change what territories are controlled by which factions, but surely the Dragonborn would be held accountable for turning the table on one of the factions?

Перевод:

Немного о том, как все было:поначалу я не очень был знакомый из серии и Скайрим как игра мне не нравилась. Прошло время игра набирала популярность и мне стало интересно что же за Скайрим почему он такой популярный.купил я его в стиме за 8 долларов, честно думаю он стоит своих денег. С самого начала игры мне понравилась атмосфера Скайрима она совсем не такая, как в других играх. Эта атмосфера живая с собственной душой. Играя в Скайрим, ты попадаешь словно в другой мир, мир драконов, геройских сказаний, мир насыщенный расами и народами, проникаешься, их культурой, обычаями, мифами. Игра на столько интересная, что можно играть часами.и она будет тебе нравиться. Геймплей: здесь можно описывать очень много, но я опишу самое основное только то что стало изюминкой для меня. Так вот с помощью двух модификации на спутника и на инвентарь я создал собственную гильдию, назвал её "Серый коготь " и вместе с шестью спутниками прошёл все квесты и основную линию Скайрима. Разнообразие брони, и навыков, помогло мне сделать из них непобедимый отряд. После мода на лошадь для спутника, я сделал их конным отрядом, с помощью которого мы уничтожали нечисть Скайрима. В какой еще игре можно такое ни в одной с тех что я знаю. Плюс игра имеет отличную музыку композитора Джереми Соул, что отлично вписываеться, в игровой процесс.

This game is an all time classic, even though it is well over a decade old. If you've never played the game as is, it could be worth it your first time through, just so when you get to the actual meat of the game (aka the hours and hours you'll spend ripping out your hair modding this game to the point of crash-to-desktop), you'll appreciate what the community has done to make this game replayable, though I would argue the special edition is the version you should get, since the game is *still* being updated with new mods, thanks to the dedicated modders of the community.

A word of wisdom as well - when modding, decide what you want the theme of the game to be. You want to do some wizardry? Heavily invest in spells. Want the game to be more of a hack and slash adventure? Invest in weapon/armor mods, combat mods that'll change up how you and the npcs will attack, etc etc. That being said, you will find this to be quickly impossible and you'll find yourself making a monstrous Frankenstein in your mods folder. This, of course, is natural, and you should enjoy it. Just keep in mind, install your mods one at a time. It *will* be tedious, but it'll save you the tremendous headache of trying to figure out which mod is the one that's making your game crash at the start.

Quick Review Time!

Skyrim is one of those rare mythical games, everyone talks about it, most people played, and dare I say it possibly influenced other games which its overwhelming success. In bland terms some may call it an rpg, though I would argue its not a very rich in terms of player choices in the quests. Nevertheless the lore, game play and world building make up for any deficiencies. I may be a bit biased since I love the lord of the rings universe and to have a rpg like this in a similar fantasy world is breathtaking.

I would also like to point out that the game is very customizable with a endless array of free modifications online, completly transforming your experience as you see fit, want to add Shrek to Tamirel? go for it, maybe sonic too? Why not. I'm a personal fan of the re-skin ones. 

Overall a really fun single player game for you to explore in a medieval fantasy world. I recommend.

Nearing 1000 hours, I can confidently say that the existence of mods made this game impossible to put down indefinitely. every few months or so I will return to Skyrim without fail. heck, now i'm trying to just do everything that this game has to offer. Still surprised to encounter new quests here and there even after all this time. Totally worth your money,

Skyrim will give odds to most modern RPGs - there are no the same type of locations and blueprinted dungeons. If one and a half cripples puffed over the creation of underground locations for Oblivion, then in Skyrim more than ten architects were involved in the design of the catacombs. Dungeons have only one drawback - almost all of them are absolutely linear. If you see a branch of the corridor, you can be sure that it ends in a dead end, where, most likely, there is a treasure chest. However, not a single game can do without stupid conventions, and you can seriously scold Skyrim only because after another thought “well, another quest, and sleep” you go to bed at three in the morning. And in our time of "one-time" games, this is worth a lot.

[h1][b]The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim[/b][/h1]

[i]Important premise: this review is based on my personal experience.[/i]

[table]
    [tr]
        [td][h1]Category[/h1][/td]
        [td][h1]Notes[/h1][/td]
        [td][h1]Score[/h1][/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Graphics[/b][/td]
        [td]
[list]
[*]Well done, considering the release date. 
[*]Well looked after settings that promote a good immersion in the game.
[/list]
[/td]
        [td] 8 / 10 [/td]
    [/tr]
        [tr]
        [td][b]Plot[/b][/td]
        [td]
[list]
[*]Well done main plot. Its quality is within the expectations.
[*]Noteworthy secondary quests for their variety, number and different developments. 
[*]There's an actual deep and rich history of Skyrim, narrated through its many books widespread across its lands. 
[/list]
[/td]
        [td] 8.5 / 10 [/td]
    [/tr]
        [tr]
        [td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
        [td]
[list]
[*]The rare bugs encountered had a negligible impact on the experience, on the overall.
[*]A poor checkpoint system that doesn't save often enough considering death is behind any corner. A manual, fast save is recommended any time.
[*]An interesting character development tree, where the abilities improve only with their use. There are also many disciplines that can be undertaken, giving the player a wide choice about the character development with countless different combinations.
[*]Fast travel unlocked in any explored area is very useful, especially when the destination to reach is very far and would require at least more than 30 minutes to be reached by foot or horse.
[/list]
[/td]
        [td] 7.5 / 10 [/td]
    [/tr]
        [tr]
        [td][b]Sound[/b][/td]
        [td] 
[list]

[*]Particularly noteworthy, well detailed and clean environmental sound effects that considerably increase the immersion into the game.
[/list]
[/td]
        [td] 8 / 10 [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Music[/b][/td]
        [td] 
[list]

[/list]
[/td]
        [td] 8 / 10 [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td][b]Overall[/b][/td]
        [td]A game I'd definitely recommend to anyone who likes the genre. For those who like reading guides, I recommend to try using the official one (or a good free on on the internet) because for sure there can be a benefit with extra suggestions and recommendations on many topics this game covers. The main plot alone lasts about 26 hours. With the secondary quests, the number increases by a lot. Definitely a game worth trying. [/td]
        [td][b] 3.9 / 5 [/b][/td]
    [/tr]      
[/table]
